description:
I can't believe I lived in the Bay Area for 4 years without coming here. 12/10 would recommend their brunch!

Came here at 12 pm on a Saturday. Essentially, you get a 90-minute slot with bottomless dim sum/menu drinks. There is usually some wiggle room for the previous party leaving and your party wrapping up - so it ends up being almost 2 hours. We called for a reservation a few days in advance and could only get bar seats for a party of 3, so plan ahead! The meal includes 15 mix & match dim sum from the menu, and different items are continuously brought out (it's kinda interesting to not be in charge of what you are going to eat - I discovered a lot of things that I wouldn't have otherwise tried!). Although portions don't seem big, they are very very filling. We couldn't make it to all 15; even 8 was an overwhelming amount of food. I highly recommend the shrimp, noodles, and the cucumber salad (trust me!). Enjoy!!
author: Margarita F.

description:
I really like Asian food. South East Asian cuisine is some of my favorite. As well as Korean food, and Japanese food.
I had high hopes for this place.
We came for dinner on a Saturday night. And damn was it loud! The music was so loud it felt like we were eating in a night club.
We ordered the garlic noodles with fried chicken. Which was pretty good. And also the Korean tacos, which was ok. 
I thought the prices were high, and the portions were small for the price.
The plating was nothing fancy, it was average.
They do have a nice beer selection. But their wine selection sucks!
With as many amazing eateries as there are in SF, I definitely will never return here. And I don't recommend anyone to waste a meal here when you can enjoy a better place for the same price or cheaper!!!
author: Anthony C.

description:
I wanted to like this place so bad but it did not cut it for me. The service and the concept was A+ but the food and drink were all consistently lacking for me.

We came here on a Sunday at their 12 pm brunch session. For those that of you that don't know, on Sundays, you need to generally make a reservation and they have 2 hour intervals where you can get unlimited drinks and dim sum. On the drinks list, they have 3 - a mimosa, sangria, and a light beer, and for the food, they have a variety of about 14-15 dishes, all varieties of fusion food influenced from Korea, China, Taiwan, etc. We walked in and they gave us a menu and told us (after looking at the menu) that all they would need is our dietary restrictions and they would give us food as they recommend. Dish by dish they came, super izakaya style. It was a totally hands-off approach and really accommodated for one of those in our group who was vegetarian.

Because I am relatively well versed in Asian food, I have a basis of all the foods that came out and was excited by the familiarity yet creative nature in the food. But all of the dishes were just slightly lacking in refinement. The drinks were (probably purposely) watered down, a bit underwhelmed overall - and the choice of a Sapporo served in a can is underwhelming. The garlic green beans, I wished could be just slightly more al dente to bring back the spring and crunchiness of the bean - and would be great to reduce the sweetness of the dish so to bring back the garlic. The jook was a bit weird too. Most jook is cooked in broth, at least the Chinese variety, and this was cooked in water served with a runny egg and crispy bacon. The flavors didn't come well together. The Korean noodles was severely lacking in noodles, although the beef was tender. The salt and pepper shrimp was tastleless unless you dipped it in the mayo, wishing for larger shrimp, less batter. The wontons my friend loved, but lacked variety in the batter, fell apart before the dish even came, and was too big of a bite. The chicken taco was certainly a remake on the Beijing duck, served on a skin similar to an onion pancake - which was creative but lacking in the hoisin sauce to bring it home for me. 

An A+ experience and great service overall but the food and drink can definitely be better. I see this restaurant as a good place to get millennials unfamiliar with Asian food introduced to the various Asian cuisines but certainly not enough for those raised on this stuff.
author: Tinaa W.

description: Spicy garlic noodles!!! Get it!!! I got it with chicken which wasn't worth it since the chicken was kinda try. The noodles are already delicious without it. The portion is big too - I had leftovers! The waiter suggested our party of 4 order 5-6 dishes since the plates were "small" but we ordered 4 and were all stuffed! The place is quite small and cramped at the booths. Definitely coming back for brunch one day!
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
I was a little skeptical of the $45 brunch, but was pleasantly surprised once the food started rolling in. We were a group of 5 and 2 of us weren't drinking, so the non-drinking price was $29 but we had to specifically ask because we were initially charged the full $45. 

That little mishap aside, the food was really good. The waiter came by and introduced himself and told us he would just be bringing food out for us throughout the 90 minutes (another slightly, but strange, thing, the 90 minute time limit). At the end we hadn't tried all 15 options so we ordered a few of the options that we hadn't had yet. I think the real winners for the day were the tacos, the dumplings, and the salt & pepper shrimp. I had a sip of each of the mimosa and the sangria and they were all good, but nothing spectacular. 

All and all, it was a pleasant surprise but didn't entirely hit it entirely out of the park for me.
author: Hannah D.

description: Solid brunch spot with great food and drinks! So you need to make a reservation (don't be late cause they only give you an hour and a half from when your reservation starts) but you can eat and drink all you want. The food is solid and the drinks are tasty, the tacos were my favorite but they have a good mix of stuff with a lot of Korean options.
author: Daniel L.

description:
LOL came here with my bf after being super hungry in sf. 

We ordered so much food. 

We got two of the noodle dishes (both were really good), wings, rib and I think one more thing. Bf got a beer too. It's a super smalll place so it's pretty cramped but none the less, service was good and food was good. 

It's def a lot more seasonings/salt compared to actual Asian food imo. 

Ended up drinking a lot of water that day. 

We found street parking in the residential area about a block away.
author: Maria A.

description:
The food at Chubby Noodle was great, but they should have a menu that caters to people with food preferences as most of the menu was meat and I couldn't eat it.

The drinks are unlimited but are very weak and have to be refilled by the server. So by the time we left, we had barely tried all the courses and hadn't drank that much since there is a time limit.

I would go back but next time with a game plan   also don't forget to ask for your free birthday shot!
author: Sydney G.

description:
My friend who was here last summer had kept talking about how great this place was all year and he was more than willing to come back here when he was back in town. He made reservations for brunch for about 7 people which I think is the max they allow. 

By the time we got there, there was already a line outside the door, but I assumed they were all people who had made reservations. The location itself is pretty small and can be pretty tight once since all the tables are relatively close to each other. 

The food itself is fairly simple and nothing really crazy. You can order whatever you like from the menu, but we decided to let the waiter pick. He got us one of everything and we ate it family style which seemed to be the best way for this place. 

The service was great as they were attentive and quick. The bottomless mimosas was awesome and despite the simplicity of the food, it was overall tasty. Overall, the experience was absolutely fantastic and I would love to do it again someday.
author: Timothy D.

description:
I'm not sure how I first discovered Chubby Noodle, but once I stopped laughing at the awesome name, I put it on my food "bucket" list. It took me a few years to go because I never visit the Marina or North Beach, but I finally found a group to go with.

I made reservations for the Marina location, which I'd highly recommend. It's a relatively small restaurant, and we had 7 people. That's about the max you'd have at a table here. And if you arrive early, there are plenty of bars around that area to hang out at. 

We ate family style, which is the way to go here. Our smorgasbord included the green beans, garlic noodles, pork ribs, beef Chow Mein, and salt & pepper shrimp. The garlic noodles and pork ribs were incredible and by far my favorite dishes. 

I like the simplicity of the food menu. It seems like there's even more sake options than food! Crazy. We also ordered a giant bottle of sake to share, and we all ended up pretty drunk. Success! I'd definitely come back for a bowl of garlic noodles and some sake.

I'd love to go to the North Beach location for another group dinner, just to compare. I'm sure it'll be just as awesome. The service is fantastic too and left me with a positive impression of Chubby Noodle. But seriously, this is the best restaurant name ever.
author: Stefanie C.

description:
There were 8 of us who came here for a brunch for a mother-daughter bonding. Cool and hip place though its really small and a little crowded. It plays music from the background a little bit blasted that people tend to talk louder than usual. It feels like you are in an afternoon-disco/club. So this is not your place to be if you want something more downcast atmosphere. This is basically more of millenial's hub since it is $45 per person for an unlimited drinks and food. Mimosas, sakes and other drinks are bottomless. They give you these little rubber duckies for every drink you order so you can also track your drinks. Isn't that fun!?! You can keep them as souvenirs if you want. So now you know what I mean, right?...;+)...Food are great and fantastic since I love plate-sharing as well and you get to taste so many of their "tapa style" servings. 
When you get there, you better have a game plan since there is a 90-minute time limit. Check their menu ahead of time and as soon as you get your seat, be ready to order however you can. Though they come in smaller portions, beware though, cause once they start pouring in, you can get overwhelmed easily lol! We ordered pretty much everything and everything is so good, so you will have no regrets whatever you will be ordering. I love it here. I think it's fun. I love the food, the service, the vibes, though i know I wont be coming here a lot since it is a bit pricey for a brunch . Only on special occasion though. Parking is always hard in the city so what do you expect. Either you take public transportation or you dont drink and drive. It's your choice
author: Theresa M.

description: The spicy garlic noodles is the way to go!  Spicy and juicy! Also, their Kung Pao wings are delicious! Highly recommend this spot.  Only down side is the parking, so if you live in the city use public transportation.
author: Yesenia L.

description:
I love this place. The first time I came it was a little odd to have a club feel during an early morning brunch but it grew on me; mostly because I loved the food. 

I have not been for regular dinner service only the weekend brunch that is all you can eat and drink within 90 minutes. I believe you do need a reservation and even if not I would highly recommend it. They get super crowded for brunch. 

For brunch there is a menu of several options. If you do not have a preference they will bring you whatever is ready which works well for timing. However there are a few items that I don't love (not that they are bad but so many more are delicious and I do not have unlimited room in my stomach) and each time I have expressed my preferences to the servers they have been great at bringing the right amount of food for each of the options I love...especially the shrimp we usually get several orders because my wife doesn't eat any other protein. 

We have returned several times with anyone who ever visits and everyone has been a fan. We will definitely be back.
author: Danielle B.

description: The food was a hit and the wait staff were on point. We had the garlic noodles, fried chicken strip, green beans, and calamari. We ordered the pork with the noodles but ended up just eating the noodles so def a hit by themselves. The green beans are not to be missed and the rest was fantastic. The atmosphere is lively with the music and people. We had a communal table with no issues.
author: Nicole A.

description:
Egg noodles were super soft, I wish they were slightly more al dente. Garlic taste comes through but isn't overpowering. A bit expensive for just straight noodles, and some many of the small garlic bits were so charred that they were hard...a bit like eating charcoal / or you had to pick them out of your food as you were eating, no bueno 3/5. This was tasty, but when do I not love egg noodles?

Poke was not bright red as much as pale red  (I understand there are all sorts of ways people gas fish to make it brighter and I totally appreciate that they don't) but the fish taste was totally overwhelmed by the soy sauce. The crushed macadamia nuts at the top were a nice touch. I had hoped that eating this with the accompanying shrimp chips (parmesan-y, what a surprise, otherwise a bit crunchier than normal shrimp chips which have a softer foamy texture), but alas it was still super salty 3/5. Shrimp chips were a nice surprise 3.5/5.
author: Nicole H.

description: Best brunch I've ever had; I was a chubby noodle indeed.
author: Willie N.

description:
Came here on a Sunday night for dinner and had heard good things about the place and food because of the AYCE brunch meal. 

We waited for about 15 minutes and saw that our table was ready long before we were actually seating. We were seated and ordered our food, and literally waited an entire hour to get our main courses. Every other table around us arrived later than us and got their food before us. The restaurant also seemed to be prioritizing takeout orders over our in-person restaurant orders. We were assured multiple times that our orders would be out quickly but the only thing we got was more time spent waiting. Additionally, the music in the restaurant seemed to get louder over the course of the night. 

The food was pretty okay in general. The portions are SO small and expensive (which is expected for SF food in the Marina), but still, $7 for a taco?! It was a good taco, but definitely not worth that price tag. The garlic noodles were pretty basic and I finished my portion within 5 minutes of getting it. My friends ordered the pad thai and chow mein, and reported that they were fine but nothing to call home about. We also ordered the poke which was just not good and a pretty poor value for the price. 

Good thing for us, the waitress apologized for the wait and offered to take some things off our bill, because I would have not paid that much for a sub-par experience and okay food. One good thing is that the  drinks menu looked pretty good, with a lot of sake options, and the descriptions were pretty entertaining. Would give this place another chance for the AYCE dimsum but otherwise not impressed.
author: Lydia S.

description:
Noodles. Dimmed lighting. Loud bumping music (like really loud). 20-30 somethings packed in tightly at the tables and the bar. 

It felt like we had been waiting for an eternity and were starving so we decided to have a beer while waiting. 

Pros: 
- Noodles
- Young crowd 
- Open late for a restaurant (till 11 pm)
- Take out available 

Things to note:
- The music is blasting. Loudly. 
Do NOT come here on a first date if you actually want to talk to the other person/don't want to be yelling the whole time. 

If you are a noodle lover you will def want to try this place out. I was taken once I read the words noodles, charred garlic, oyster sauce, hoisin, jalapeño and cilantro. Yum yum gimme all the noodz! Food was good, I'd come back to try out other dishes. I've tried take out before but it doesn't taste the same :( if you're gonna try chubby noodle out then plan to eat there!
author: Saachi G.

description:
No AC so it was pretty small and packed, but the food was great. The Korean tacos were definitely my favourite, order a lot of those!! 5/5 for the Korean tacos! 

The seats are really close together, my friend got hit in the face by someone's hair from the booth behind him. Good for rowdy groups that want to eat Korean tacos and sake.
author: Phillis Y.

description: The brunch deal is amazing. The reserve tables for 90 minutes at a team and the entire restaurant is seated and exited at the same time. For $45 you get a LOT of food and alcohol. They are very liberal with serving, the staff is amazing, the food tastes pretty good, and the vibe is really fun. You don't have to order anything off the menu - everything is brought to your table. Great place for a fun, bottomless brunch. Definitely recommend!
author: Aakanksha M.

description:
Dang, how I wish I wasn't all by myself on my visit here. All shared plates but I wanted to try everything.
The spicey noodles were the bomb and so was the chicken wings. I actually shared the wings with the table next to me so they wouldn't go to waste. Now if I could only convince the owners to open a place in Seattle...
Go early, the place is small and fills up quick. But whatever you do...try it.
author: Jim P.

description:
Wasn't impressed to say the least. I had called ahead of time to see if there was a wait and the host said there wasn't and to come on down. Once we arrived which was about 10 mins later, the host told us there was a wait but not to worry because we will get the next booth. So we decided to sit at the bar in the mean time. We ordered some drinks at the bar and the bartender whose name is Marco was amazing! So attending to us and easy to talk to (Honestly he was the only highlight of the night). The host eventually came back to us to seat us and he ended up sitting us in the far back corner with a tiny little table that would rock back and forth and not the booth that he originally promised us.

Then we met our server, he was alright I just wish he was more attentive. He didn't come once to check on us after we received our food to see how we liked it. Every time we needed something we kept having to wave our hands and try to get someone else's attention to come to our table.

The food:
The food was tasteless.. its as if they just put a bunch of hot spices so that you don't realize there's no flavor because your mouth is on fire. We ordered the spicy garlic noodles which was $11 with a $5 upcharge to add fried chicken. What a rip off. Will never recommend this place to anyone.
We also ordered the green beans and the Calamari and that was average.

Overall our experience wasn't great. I would only go back to visit Marco because he was the only highlight of our night. What a cool dude he was!
author: Hadeel A.

description: The food was delicious so I would definitely go back; the loud and boisterous environment (small space with many people crammed in trying to speak over blasting music) was stressful for me and not my favorite, hence the four stars. If you're looking for a good time, it's a good place. If you're looking for a quiet dinner, either order out or go elsewhere :)
author: Shelby S.

description:
Came here with a bunch of friends and I was pleasantly surprised. I wasn't expecting the food to be great as I knew coming it was an all you can eat place and i frankly haven't had the best experience at buffets. 

I don't eat meat and after telling the server my dietary needs he brought out dish after dish of modified dishes to cater to my dietary needs, I.e. subbing out the XO sauce with a veg sauce on the bok Choy. At one point, there was probably more veg dishes on the table than meat ones. 

Drink service was very attentive and the server (despite being the only drink server) made sure my sangria was never empty. 

-1 star for being out of the alcoholic tea drink that I was v excited to try. Considering there was only 4 drinks to choose from and it was still early in the day (a Sunday too), it was a bit of a bummer they were out. 

That being said, as a vegetarian brunch fanatic, I highly recommend this spot and I will be back.
author: austin y.

description:
Went here at 7pm on a Saturday. We walked in and there was a 45 minute wait, but the bar was empty and they served food, so we sat down.

We didn't order drinks and the bartender was obviously perturbed by this. The nice friendly service was taken down a few notches. 

Food was good, we were seated near the kitchen so saw a lot of dishes that came out and they looked great too.
author: Shannon M.

description:
Not long ago, a startup called Leap offered blinged-out $6 shuttles from the Marina to FiDi, complete with a snack bar serving yogurt, energy bars, $7 fresh-pressed juices, and Blue Bottle iced coffee. Among other things, Leap claimed that there was an underserved market for transit in the Marina. Never mind the fact that it's already served by the MUNI 30, 30X, 41, and 45 lines which all run through Chinatown. Notably, Leap riders interviewed by the press often expressed an aversion to MUNI buses, saying that they couldn't deal with all the crowds. Translation: that trip through Chinatown was beneath them, and they just couldn't bother to mingle with folks of ethnic ilk.

A similar dynamic is at play with Chubby Noodle, even if the setting is less blingy and more douchey - complete with a logo that - dude! - is a blatant Asian caricature. In a city whose population is one-third Asian, there are plenty of places for authentic, down-home Asian fare. For the life of me, I can't understand why anyone would prefer the bland and often sad offerings here over the real thing - unless you just don't want to burst your neighborhood bubble on a weekend morning and prefer a deafening, brotastic atmosphere with some cultural appropriation served on the side. 

Perhaps the best thing about the brunch experience is that it's AYCE, including some fairly weak drinks. To start, a bowl of breakfast jook tried to gussy up a Chinese staple with a dash of toppings like smoked bacon, but the actual congee itself was utterly bland and watery. While Chinese folks do indeed use whatever toppings they want, the underlying congee should hold its own without them - in the same vein that, say, oatmeal should. Then again, how many patrons here have actually gone to Chinatown, the Richmond, or the Sunset for a proper bowl of congee? Cue the sound of crickets.

Veggies like the Szechuan green beans and the bok choy with mushrooms were more acceptable, although these are items that are hard to screw up. Of course, the fact that they're listed as "wok tossed" on the menu (itself quite a piece of work) must really impress folks who have never touched a wok before. Sure must conjure up exotic images of, say, Bruce Lee going all kung fu fighting. Meanwhile, the pork wontons and pork buns were passable, although I've had similar results from frozen fare. Similarly, the chubby chicken chow mein must be a good enough mess if you're simply not used to eating at real Chinese restaurants that prepare pan-fried noodles to crispy perfection.

Look, I get it. For many people, heading into Chinese or Asian neighborhoods means straying too far from their comfort zones. If a fundamental lack of understanding of the cuisine doesn't already impede optimum menu choices from the get-go, brusque service and language barriers at many hole-in-the-wall Asian joints don't help either. So it's far less of an assault on the untrained psyche to sanitize, if not bastardize, the cuisine for non-Asian tastes and eliminate Asians from customer-facing positions - and the entire staff altogether.

Add in an utterly boorish, obnoxious crowd and some deafening overhead music - "what better way to eat noodles than with R. Kelly singing in the background?" as the web site suggests - and you've got a douchetastic venue perfectly suited to the neighborhood. And you don't even have to expose yourself to those folks on the 30-Stockton? Now that's hashtag winning, bro! 

In the end, maybe it's a good thing that there are places like this to soak up the kind of folks who would gravitate to them anyway. Leave good places elsewhere in the city for folks who can truly appreciate, understand, and enjoy them. But beware - many of the fawning reviews here look like paid reviews.
author: Vincent L.

description:
The worst restaurant experience I've ever had in San Francisco.
1.We were told to leave our seats right after being seated because they were reserved. 
2. No one came to serve us water after we asked or came to take our order or tell us to order food in the front. 
3. The noodles were served in a to-go box was ridiculous given we were discussing about where to be seated and the waitress was obviously aware of we are having the food here. 
4. After we asked for two bowls, they were served with two spoons. How are you supposed to eat noodle with spoons?! 
5. The noodles were broken and the fried chicken was too dry, the food was awful.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
Favorite brunch place of all time. All you can eat AND all you can drink. I love this restaurant soo much. They always play the best hiphop and the staff are always super friendly. It's such a lovable place. 

My friends and I came here a bit way too often. We always have to make reservations though because it gets quite busy since everyone wants all you can eat and drink. The drinks are super cute. They usually put a rubber ducky in it. The food is closer to the Asian side, but it's like tapa style. So smaller portions, but don't let that fool you. We got a lot and we couldn't even finish. 

My favorite is the string beans and the wonton soup. Those were always so great for me in the morning! Also, the porridge. Not sure if they have those now. But those were my favorite. It's a small place so I suggest don't go with a group bigger than 5. It'll get real snug. 

Overall, awesome place!
author: Frances T.

description: This little noodle spot looked amazing as I walked by and was not disappointed. Awesome atmosphere, cool vibes, great music, and the food was amazing. I had some noodles with bbq pork on top that were fantastic. I would definitely recommend going there.
author: David B.

description:
Two stars because the food was tasteless and not good. We love fusion restaurants but our meal was bland.

The freshest ingredient on our plates was the green onion garnish.

Ambiance was fun, music was great. 

We ordered:

Kimchi: something was missing and the cabbage was soggy and a little damp moldy smell to it

Cucumber salad: surprisingly the best thing we ordered, the rice vinegar is sweet and a refreshing 

Szechuan Green Beans: overcooked, blistered with no crunch or flavor

"Spicy" Garlic Noodles with shrimp: they forgot the shrimp at first, added the shrimp after and to our surprise it was unseasoned and plain. Noodles were okay, no incredible flavor, no spice

Korean Pork Tacos: fatty meat, I was expecting more tender pieces of meat. in house tortilla was good
author: Stephanie E.

description:
A decent experience at Chubby Noodle. I went here early in the evening by myself and was seated at the "bar", a little nook by the door. Service was prompt and responsive enough. It's a small place, so I can see it filling up pretty quickly during the dinner rush.

I started with the kimchi as a small appetizer. Huge mistake. This is the worst kimchi I've ever had. It was weak, watery, and nearly entirely flavorless. Stay away at all costs. 

The spicy garlic noodles, however, were quite pleasant! I wouldn't even call them spicy; there was just enough heat for it to register. The garlic flavor is pleasantly strong, and the noodle/garlic combo is substantial without making me feel super heavy after eating. 

Overall, I think Chubby Noodle is fine. The garlic noodles are good, and I'd be interested in seeing how the other noodles hold up.
author: Chris D.

description:
Now this place is a party! Excellent service, bottomless sangria/mimosa/drinks, and endless food all for about 39 bucks (without tax and gratuity)

Why I was here // We got together with my bf's cousins from the east coast after running a 15k at Golden Gate Park. Nothing like ending a long run with some heavy food and drinks.

The Process // Reservations are a must! This place gets packed and brunch is only from 10am-2:30pm on Saturday and Sunday. 

Service // AMAZING service! Our hosts did an excellent job of picking out entrees and keeping the food coming! All of us were so happily stuffed at the end of this. Also shout out to the bomb drink man who kept the cantelope mimosas going. 

Food // 
-Hot & Sour Soup = probably my favorite thing on the menu. 
-Pickled things = the cucumbers weren't too flavorful but it had a refreshing crunch. 
-pork buns = delicious, the bread is soo good
-salt and pepper shrimp= extremely flavorful 
-chubby chicken chow mein = basic chow mein 
-- we definitely had some other dishes come our way thats not on our list, because there was just so much food! 

Overall // The brunch price is perfect if you are going for the bottomless drinks. I don't really drink so I probably wouldn't pay 40 bucks for their brunch since the food is on the heavier side. I definitely recommend this as a place to have a good time with friends, but not so much for a romantic date, since the music is pretty loud. Can't really hear people talk.
author: Emily T.

description:
Came here with a friend for a dinner on a Saturday night and left wondering how this place had 4 stars. Servers were polite and the space was nice though I wasn't a fan of the small tables in the back where we were seated. My bigger issue was the music which in terms of selection was great but in terms of volume was absolutely deafening. My friend and I felt like we were shouting across our tiny 2 foot table.

For our meal we got the tuna poke, the korean pork tacos, and the spicy garlic noodles.

-Tuna Poke: One of the worst tuna pokes I've ever had but I see raw fish and I want it. The quality of the tuna was pretty bad. Really mushy with little to no flavor. Or maybe that's just because it was soaked half a bottle of soy sauce so I couldn't taste anything else besides salt. Either way, definitely skip this (1/5)

-Korean Pork Tacos: The only good item of the day but was overpriced at $6 per taco. The meat was a bit salty though the flavors were good. The best part was definitely the tortilla. Everything was balanced and delicious but also something you can easily make at home for a fraction of the price (with the exception of the tortilla).

-Spicy Garlic Noodles: I love garlic noodles so damn much. I want garlic infused into every last bite of it so I can die and go to garlic heaven. This got me to garlic purgatory. It's nowhere near garlic-y enough. The flavors weren't bad otherwise though I found the noodles to be a bit overcooked. Price is alright for the portion.

Overall, I left extremely disappointed. Definitely will pass on the dinner menu in the future. Though I am still slightly tempted by their brunch menu...
author: Vivian C.

description: This place is AWESOME!  Came here with a few friends and fell absolutely in love.  First, this place is small.  I suggest either ordering to go or preparing yourself for a wait.  Next, this place has an amazing energy.  There is visibility to the kitchen and rap music is always playing.  Last, the food - delicious.  I got the spicy garlic noodles with tofu and I loved it.  The flavor was amazing, portion was a good size and it was very well prepared.  We also shared some beans as a table.  I loved the soy sauce and the fact that they were topped with some sliced almonds.  I would recommend this place to both locals and visitors
author: Danielle N.

description:
I went here last night and I would definitely recommend this place to my friends! 

First of all the music that they play here is amazing! a lot of great old school hip hop that puts you in a good/nostalgic mood. 

My date and I ordered the garlic noodles with fried chicken, the korean pork tacos and the Szechuan green beans. My least favorite part about the meal was the fried chicken in the garlic noodles, I didn't think it was worth the extra $5. The chicken wasn't bad but they just reminded me of cut up pieces of chicken tenders. The green beans and the korean pork tacos were BOMB omg! The garlic noodles were amazing as well but the taco and the green beans were definitely the stars. 

I can't wait to come back to for dim sum brunch!
author: Danielle D.

description: Spicy fried chicken noodle. It's so dang good! The place is always packed, so because of this and one in our party wasn't well we decided to order take out. The menu is small but their food is delicious! The service is awesome too, they keep the flow fair and moving. Everyone is happy. They made a special bland roasted chicken noodle for my sick hubby back at the hotel, they suggested it as they make it for children, it was perfect! If you are in the area, I definitely recommend for tasty, efficient, friendly dining experience!
author: Shannon C.

description:
Second time at Chubby Noodle but different location and I was underwhelmed again. What's with the music for a Sunday night, it was pretty obscene rap music. I might understand it for a Fri/Sat night but a Sunday?! Had the garlic noodles @ $11 and add on fried chicken for $5 it wasn't worth the price. The garlic noodles weren't bad but just didn't have the wow factor. 

Service was ok as everyone got all of our dishes fairly quickly but one person didn't get there's until we were almost finished. 

Bug alert: saw a cockroach crawling on the window of the food prep/kitchen. The guys in the kitchen just looked at it and kept on cooking. It's good for late night drunkie eating imo and that's about it.
author: James H.

description:
Loved this. The four of us weren't terribly hungry so we shared three plates and loved them all. We had the spicy green beans, spicy garlic noodles with fried chicken, and kale salad. Each of us had a different favorite. We had a peak at the fried  rice and curry noodles and felt like we made the right decision. Very pleased with our experience. 

Only thing I would change is turning down the music a little. I had a hard time hearing over the people and the rap.
author: P. A.

description:
My friend brought me here for a late dinner Thursday night. He loves the place since it's close to his house so I was excited to try it out. 

We ordered the garlic noodles with fried chicken, pork ribs, pork tacos, salt and pepper shrimp and some nigori to share. 

The taste was on point. My favorite were the pork ribs, they were tender and came right off the bone. I love how they put jalapeños in everything, providing the extra kick in the already flavorful dishes.
author: Maggi W.

description:
I love variety. When our office lunch showed up and no one claimed the extra item from Chubby Noodle, I decided to grab it! Plus, it's an excuse to have a second lunch. (Turned out someone was sick, so lucky me! I got to eat their lunch.) Our order arrived via Caviar on Friday, June 16th a little before 12 noon.

I ended up with an order of Spicy Garlic Noodles: House made egg noodles, garlic, jalapeno ($11). I've had them before from the North Beach location, so I knew I adored these noodles. Chewy, garlicky, and delicious! Plus, it was a hefty portion. The only thing that left me wanting was the lack of spiciness. I remember the noodles having sliced jalapenos and more of a kick. These were rather mild and I didn't see much jalapeno. I couldn't finish the order, so I gave the rest to a coworker. I think I was able to eat a good third of the box. They were that good. Plus, I had already had a bunch of food from anther spot a little earlier.

Good place for garlic noodles. If you want some kick though, I'd note extra spicy with your order. That was the only thing lacking from this dish. Otherwise, my tummy was very happy.
author: Elena N.

description:
Definitely a one of a kind brunch experience! 

I had been to Chubby Noodle for dinner before and didn't quite understand the hype. The food was good, but with so many Chinese restaurants in the city I felt a little misled. 

But now that I've done brunch I totally get it. 90 minutes of bottomless drinks (cold tea, mimosa, sangria, sake) AND dim sum. All of this set to some bumpin' hip hop and a party vibe. It was so much fun, especially with a big group of friends. The drinks were definitely strong which I was all for, and the food was also so good! Standouts for me were the green beans, the chicken lettuce wraps, pork buns, and dumplings. 

If you do brunch right, you won't want to plan to do anything super active when you're done. I staggered out of there and went straight to Dolores Park :)
author: Sophie S.

description: I have to laugh at myself. I was looking for a quick and quiet dinner cuz it was late at night. I ended up in this place with loud popping hiphop music with a yuppy crowd. I was even treated to a scene of grinding and gyrating. Forget about the food! The party is here! Well, i was still hungry so I ended up getting the Curry Lemongrass Vermicelli. The server was very sweet and helpful. Her name was Katia. I told her I was looking for something with noodles and meat/protein but also with lots of veggies.  She cheerfully told me she would ask the chefs. I love people who say it is possible...She came back with a list of different veggies red bell pepper spinach scallion bean sprouts mint and basil to add to my noodle dish. It was delish! I approved!  The roasted chicken was well marinated and perfectly tender. The dish was just lightly flavored with coconut that lent a little richness to the dish. Overall it was a really balanced dish that had a little chilly pepper heat. I really liked sitting at the high table, looking over to the kitchen at the busy all Latino cooks. By the end of my meal I dot know what is louder, the music, the clanking of dishes being cleaned up, or the ringing in my ears. Next time i will bring my decible meter to see if it violates OSHA noise level at work place. LOL! The workers need to be protected. 5 stars for food and service, take off one star for the loud music.
author: Thuy V.

description:
Came here for a date night with my husband. We were seated right away right away at the high top tables next to the kitchen. I enjoyed watching the chefs cook.

Music could be softer here, it's a restaurant, not a night club....

We ordered the following 
-salmon sashimi
-garlic noodles with fried chicken
-calamari

By far our fave was the salmon sashimi and calamari, we could care less for the garlic noodles. For the price of $11 plus another $5 for the fries chicken, the noodles were just not worth it.
The chicken also tasted like Tyson popcorn chicken.

The sashimi on the other hand was soooo fresh and so freaken good. I love ponzu and salmon combined and the avocado inside just tied everything together!!! I want to eat like 20 pieces of just this but that'll be a pretty hefty tab! 

The calamari was super good and had a really good dipping sauce. Reminds me of the calamari they serve at the Farmer's Union in San Jose. I wish they would just serve a whole plate of calamari heads, love the crispy tentacles the most, I can care less about calamari rings! 

Overall, I would be back but would like the music to be turned down a bit and to try something new!
author: Kelly L.

description:
This place would have been a 4-5 star, but I had to knock it a bit for reasons I'll mention below. 

First off, I have to say I like the aesthetic of this spot .... the only way to describe it is 'Hipster Dim Dum' ... make of that what you will. The people are very nice, but kind of aloof (which I don't mind). The ambiance is nice, but the seats are fairly small and parties of more than 6 are really not doable. 

I like the concept of their pricing a lot. $39 for an all you can eat/drink brunch with a fair amount of options. Our hostess suggested a tasting of everything, and we couldn't resist. There was a ton of food, and we all ate until they had to roll us out. You have a total of 1.5 hours to eat/drink all you can, but that's plenty of time. 

I have to say for an AYCE type of place, I really thought the food flavors were on point for the most part. There were a few misses, but definitely more hits. For me some of the hits were the green beans, the chicken wraps and the dumplings. The fried rice and the veggie platter (bok choi and mushrooms) were the most disappointing. 

One thing I would have liked to see was better drinks. It tastes like they're not using the best champagne for their drinks... which I guess is to be expected, but the flavors really didn't do it for me for the drinks. 

Now, I also have to disclose that whoever was preparing the drinks while I was there was kinda dropping the ball. The first round of drinks we got were mimosas. I was drinking mine when a friend noticed some pulp in my glass... I thought it was OJ, but then pulled out a wad of paper from the bottom of my cup :x (another friend found one in hers as well). The waitress apologized and brought us a round of sake shots to make up for it, which was super cool. We all got a second round of drinks, and I opted for the sangria that time. When it arrived it had a little rubber ducky in it (all the drinks do) and the rubber ducky had a dead fly on it. The waitress apologized again, but I gotta say it kinda put me off of the drinks. 

Overall the deal you get here is great, and the food is mostly delicious, but the preparation of the drinks really had me questioning the cleanliness of what was happening behind the curtains. I'd still recommend this place for a good brunch spot, but some improvements could be made. 

Stay Cheerful ;)
author: Garen A.

description:
Our group of 5 had the bottomless dim sum brunch on Sunday afternoon. We started with the "hoang" mimosa: sparkling, house squeezed watermelon juice and then tried the Jose rose sangria: red Zinfandel, five-spice, pineapple, apple, squirt. The service was fast and the speakers played Drake, The Weeknd, and other hip hop/rap. The food came out in rapid succession a little bit before the midpoint of the meal. 45 bucks not including Uncle Sam & gratitude was a fair price. Good place to take a friend from out of town or a music lover.

Breakfast jook: smoked bacon, egg, chili oil, charred garlic, scallions. Best dish to me.

Salt & pepper shrimp: garlic, chilies, cilantro, basil. Table favorite. Sauce was exceptional

Lemongrass chicken tacos: hoisin, cucumber, scallions.

Hangover stew: stewed pork, kimchi, top ramen. Spicier than a massage parlor mamasan!

Veggie fried rice: egg, vegetable, scallion. Went well with other meat dishes.

Cucumber salad: pickled cucumber, sesame seeds. Served first. Appetizing!

Dan dan noodles: pork,undo noodles, spicy peanut butter sauce.

Chicken chow mein: charred vegetables, egg noodles, scallions.

Szechuan green beans: oyster sauce, black vinegar, ginger.

Pork wontons: cilantro, scallions, ponzu.
author: Alan V.

description: Go for the experience, not the food or drinks. The service is great and the music makes it a fun environment. The food is unique takes on dim sum. I personally prefer the more traditional dim sum. I still had a great time though!
author: Sara S.

description: I've never eaten here but have ordered on Cavier a few times - they give generous takeaway portions and the food is always hot and delicious!
author: Lady N.

description:
I ordered food from this restaurant during rush hour. The food was okay. I wanted to know what the hyped was all about but it's not the best or was it really good. 
I would like it if the added more favor to their dishes. I was a bit disappointed when I had my first bite of the spicy garlic noodles with roast pork, it was really dry and no favor at it. 
The salt and pepper shrimp, was really soggy and wasn't crispy at all.
author: Bee T.

description:
I've been wanting to check this place out for almost a year since a friend recommended the tacos and I finally stopped in after WCC the other day. I considered ordering takeout numerous times but I'm glad I actually came in! The place has very laid-back/hip/beachy vibes--I almost felt like I was in Santa Monica. 

Stephanie, my server/bartender, was incredibly hospitable. I think she actually made the entire experience 100x more enjoyable, to be honest. She also whipped up a bomb cocktail called "Tough Titty Said the Kitty"--it was creamy, sweet, tropical, spicy, and refreshing! 

The Korean Pork Tacos? Unreal. Super generous portions and insanely flavorful. I wish I had come with a bigger group/appetite so I could try way more food. 

Well worth the wait. 10/10 would come back for more.
author: Nikki I.

description:
Came Back this time for Sunday Brunch....

Serving can be small Plates but with the 14 Mix and Match Small Plates !!! and Their Unlimited Mimosas, Sangria, Sapporo !!! Their all good !!!

Their Salt and Pepper Shrimp got 2 orders is GOOD..
Peking Duck
Pork Buns
Kung Pao Wings among my Favorite

Better be here soon as they Open...as it get busy (90Mins dine-in all the food you could eat) Its more than enough for us to be completely filled up....

Wait time for us was 1hr 30mins they took my contact number to call me when tables ready(for the meantime had a stroll around chestnut )

Its worth the wait...

Mark looks like the manager was friendly...even on a very busy small place he still managed to check on all tables..

Will be Back...

TIP:::::
Crowd mostly hipster...can be very Loud..( if you hate loud crowd this might not be your Place)
author: Donovan L.

description:
Really well done - garlic noodles were excellent (with fried chicken) 
Pork tacos
Green beans 
Salt and pepper shrimp 
All the recommended (and cliché "signature") items 
Excellent nigori to go with it it
Def coming back !!
author: Dan B.

description:
Great value, service, music, room--will be going back (to get more spicy garlic noodles). The service was great, they really care about your experience. One of the best dining experiences we've had in SF.

For 4 people, we got 5 dishes (~70$) and were pleasantly full. Spicy garlic noodles, tacos, tacos again, vermicelli, Szechuan green beans.
author: Chad L.

description:
Very disappointed with the service at Chubby Noodle tonight, and we never even got to try the food...
A group of 3 friends and I arrived around 7:30 on a Saturday night and the wait time was around 1 hour... to be expected on a busy Saturday night. 
Friends and I walked around the Marina district for an hour, and we still hadn't gotten a text saying that our table was ready. We returned to Chubby Noodle, and the girl at the front told us it was going to be at least 30 minutes more. However, there were a ton of open tables and not many people inside of the restaurant. Seemed kind of fishy from that time on. 
At that point, we decided to leave if it was going to be so much longer. At 10pm (2 1/2 hours later), we called and asked how much longer it would be. The girl at the front said "Yeah, it's just really busy" and then trailed off.
A wait that extensive is absolutely ridiculous, and we saw people seated inside of the restaurant who had arrived after us to wait for a table. I totally get that it's a busy Saturday night, but it seemed like that they lost track of our table despite checking in several times and didn't seem to care.
I really wanted to try this place and the food, but I don't want to trust them when an 1 hour wait somehow turns into 2 1/2 and you are forgotten about! Very bad customer service in my opinion and it makes me not want to go back if getting a table is such an ordeal.
author: Meredith R.

description:
I feel like Chubby Noodle is a right of passage for brunch in SF. This place is a Marina gem and isn't easy to miss with the big noodle bowl in front. From the moment you walk in you're greeted with Drake and other hip hop classics. I never imagined eating dimsum/using chopsticks with Bodak Yellow playing the background but it happened. haha. 

It's around $40 for bottomless mimosas + food. Basically they come around with 1 of each dish on their menu so it's easy to try a little of everything. Things are served family style so be sure to eat & drink a lot to make your money worth. 

My fave dishes were definitely the baos. The pork buns and peking duck were so tasty! They pair the baos with plenty of meat so it pairs well to soak up all the alcohol you're drinking. 

We also tried the 

+ Salt & Pepper Shrimp - Not too salty and it pairs well with the sauce they give you.

+ Shrimp Fried Rice - My least favorite. The flavors were lacking and it tasted like the rice was just made vs day old.

+ Chow Mein - I like that they had the regular noodles with crunchy noodles as well. It was tasty and not too oily.

+ Breakfast Porridge - Yum! They don't really give that many spoons so be sure to ask for extra ones. I like the addition of bacon and it's a great feel good option especially when you're drinking. 

+ Green Beans - I enjoyed this dish! They were sauteed in a nice sauce that wasn't too overpowering that made the beans feel overcooked. 

+ Bok Choy & Mushrooms - nothing too special but it was a nice contrast to all the savory flavors.

+ Fried Chicken - not the best in my opinion. There was definitely a small amount of meat for what it was.

The drinks here are meh. The sangria tasted watered down and more like punch. I would definitely recommend the cantaloupe over the sangria. 

Service is pretty attentive to coming around often to fill up your cups w/ their little ducks, but they are strict on time so be sure to listen to how much time you have left. The place is loud so I found myself having to raise my voice to chat with the people around me. It's also a small place so it does get warm. I recommend not coming too layered since all the body heat and warmth from the kitchen radiates throughout the whole place.

Parking is hard in the Marina so be sure to come early to make sure you make the most of your  time or early enough to beat the lines.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
I've had chubby noodle bookmarked since I've moved to the city two years ago and I can't believe I waited this long to give it a try. I kick myself for not trying it sooner but I'm glad I did. Everything I ordered was on point and awesome. The fact that they even have Hinano beer on the menu made me love this place even more. 

OK yeah this place is loud a little bit louder than I usually enjoy.. but do yourself a favor and just maybe have like a few Hinano's and you'll be fine.
author: Ervin D.

description: I moved to SF! And with a new city comes new eats for me to try. Chubby Noodle was a delicious meal. I shared the spicy garlic noodles and the salt & pepper shrimp with my friend plus a bowl of rice between us and it was the perfect amount of food. We paid $4 extra to add char sui bbq pork to the noodles and this was a great move because they gave us so much pork!! We left there with contented stomachs and wallets. Everything was very flavorful and nothing was too salty. This is a meal I am definitely willing to repeat :) Great job Chubby Noodle.
author: Candace L.

description:
This place blew my mind! First of all, let me start by saying I was served the best tacos I've ever eaten from anyone, ever. The shells were handmade and the pork was tender and perfectly marinated making every bite an event. We had a huge assortment of food, from small bites, to salad, veggies, sashimi to noodles....they all delivered in their own way. This was one of those nights I wished for a secret trap door in my belly so I could quickly make room for more food simply so I wouldn't have to stop eating. 
Diners beware, the place is smoky, at first it's nearly overwhelming but I quickly became acclimated and I have a sensitive sniffer. They had a window open, which didn't seem to offer much help but I can't imagine what it would have been like if it hadn't been open. You will leave smelling like the seared noodles from their kitchen, you can be sure of that. The music played was nearly at dance club volume and was new and classic hip hop. We loved it and learned they even have their own music station on Spotify (and now we're listening to that, thanks!), but it may be a deterrent for some. 
This place is amazing!! I'm coming back!
author: Lauren E.

description:
This place came highly recommended and it delivered.  It is a small 12 or so table establishment with delicious food.  We had the spicy green beans, noodles with pork and the duck lettuce wraps.

The spicy green beans were a teriyaki style sauce with a bit of kick.  The green beans were tender and perfectly cooked.

The noodles with pork were also very good.  The pork will taste familiar as it has sort of a pink sauce and almost candy tasting.

The duck stole the show though.  Crispy, greasy goodness and a huge portion.  The lettuce was butter lettuce and came with a hoisen sauce and carrots and cucumbers.

Service was pretty good for a bar seat.

Can't wait to try some more of their stuff next time!
author: Mark W.

description:
One of the best comfort food options in SF. Love the Garlic Noodles and their fried chicken is SO good!

I would recommend going here with a bunch of friends.
author: Saad Z.

description:
Hmm... I think the food was okay-good, but not amazing... I probably wouldn't come out of the way to eat here again. Note that I only came here for dinner, and not their brunch.

It does get quite smokey/warm in here since there's an open kitchen. So be prepared to choke and cough here and there when they cook with tons of szechuan peppers. 

Their garlic noodles were delicious, but I can't quite remember what else we got. So unfortunately, not memorable for me.

I would only come back to try brunch...
author: Janet H.

description:
They are liars!!! Or racist...or sexist? 

This is based on my experience on 5/25, Saturday Lunch time for 3 people. I didn't get to try there food but was able to experience some bullshit. Here 's what happened:

We called around 11:50am to see if they take reservations and if there is wait. The person who answered the phone said they do not take reservations but we can just come-in. So we drove down. 
We arrived at 12:15pm. The restaurant was full. The host said they are completely booked(?) for lunch and cannot serve us as they close at 2pm for mid-time. 
Since the place was fully "booked" and we cannot sit, we asked if we can do take-out orders. The host said "we do not take to-go orders, sorry." 

Here are reasons why I think they are liars or discriminators:
1. They should've told us in the first place that they are fully booked for the lunch so do not waste your time, gas, and meter parking fee for nothing. 
2. How can you not have table turn around for 1.5 hrs? If you don't take reservations, how can you be fully booked and not take other customers? This just doesn't make any sense. Or are you just not taking non-white people? 
3. I knew they do take-out orders as me and my friend did to-go before. How can they lie straight to the face? Plus, I posted question on Yelp if this place do take-out orders right there and got 2 answers with 'Yes.' You guys better officially announce that you only serve dine-in from now and explain to me if you don't take to-go orders only from us?
author: Rachel K.

description:
Decided to come her for their brunch special, which is basically $37 all you can eat dim sum/asian food with bottomless drinks. 

If you're under 21 or a college student with a budget, then you might want to reconsider checking out this place. $37+gratuity+tax totaled up to about $50 per person. If you also don't like to drink or cannot drink, then you might also want to consider that too since the bartenders couldn't make any virgin drinks other than their honeydew juice, which was delicious. Any additional virgin/non-alcoholic drinks would be additional costs. 

Nonetheless, if pricing does not matter to you, then this place is a pretty good! Although the music can be a little loud, my friends and I were really liking their playlist. The food was also delicious!! It was flavorful and their ingredients seemed fresh! 

I would probably come here again for a special occasion with friends!
author: Joyce W.

description: Yumm! This place is super fun and loud. The music is blasting and just a great time all around. There is a 90 minute time limit, which goes by so quick. Overall, really good service. Both the food and drinks come out quickly. Some of the dishes are better than others, but they're mainly good. For drinks, I preferred the sangrias over the mimosas. The mimosas were super watered down but hey, still did it. I really liked the experience I had here. Definitely would come back!
author: Annie H.

description:
Good food, good drinks, and good vibe if you're willing to wait forever. I was in a party of three at 6 on a Saturday night. They had three seats left at the bar or we could wait about an hour... we chose bar.

It wasn't actually a bad set-up at all - the bartender was attentive and made suggestions. We ordered drinks and a few dishes for a lighter dinner since it was early.

- KOBE BEEF CHOW MEIN: really flavorful and chewy noodles
- KOREAN PORK TACOS: also really flavorful with interesting textured bites
- PORK RIBS: ...flavorful! Haha definitely heavy on the taste buds kinda restaurant which I like. Would have definitely ordered a lighter salad to balance everything out. The flavors on these ribs were reminiscent of a sweet and sour Chinese meat dish. You know what I mean.

I definitely want to be back though - loved the vibe and the dim lighting (which is something I NEVER say but it worked).
author: Lucy Z.

description:
Here's the thing... everything we had tasted good, but tasty is easy to achieve when everything is fried.  You could deep fry a sock and it would taste good, but you may regret eating it later.  Such is the case with Chubby Noodle.

The service was friendly and our orders arrived quickly. I like the look of the place.  The drink menu is serviceable but underwhelming.  And the food is good and oily.
author: Ron P.

description:
I was really torn between giving this place 3 or 4 stars, but I gave it 4 because my friends and I ended up having a lot of fun here. I'll break it down: 

FOOD: 
I really enjoyed the food. Obviously not authentic Chinese food, but who on earth would come to Chubby Noodle expecting it to be "authentic" anyways? Doesn't matter. What matters is that it tasted delicious. They started just bringing dishes out without us having to order anything, which I really liked because it gave us a taste of everything on their menu. Only downside is a lot of my friends don't eat pork and many of the dishes here had pork. If I came again, I would specify which dishes to bring out so that nothing goes to waste. I LOVED the buns, the shrimp fried rice, and the Chubby Noodles. I also loved that we could order as much as we wanted of anything. 

DRINKS:
Prepare yourselves because I have a lot of horrible things to say about the drinks here. I have been to a lot of bottomless mimsoa places, and I don't think I've ever been so blatantly jipped by a restaurant when it comes to drinks than we were here. The strawberry mimosas were SO SO SO watered down. They tasted like maybe they made the mimosas yesterday, let it sit in a shit ton of melting ice, and then decided to serve it to us the next day. It didn't even taste like there was champagne in there, just watered down strawberry juice. Since we only had 90 mins, we ended up drinking at least 7-10 of these each because they weren't really doing the trick. My friend ordered the sangria, which just tasted like a bad vodka cranberry. You could really taste the vodka in there which I found strange because.... it's Sangria. Finally, when the waiter came around to re-fill our drinks, we had 10 minutes left of eating/drinking time. I know this because I was keeping track very carefully. When he poured our drinks, he said "this is last call for the drinks". I'm sorry, we still had 10 minutes left and we are paying customers, who are you to tell me that this is going to be my last glass? Again, I've never been to a bottomless mimosa place where they enforced the time limit so much that they cut you off before the 90-minute mark. And no we were not being rowdy/overly drunk, they were just being cheap. 

Anyways, definitely an experience, definitely recommend checking it out but definitely not my favorite brunch place.
author: Zoe B.

description:
I think Cubby Noodle is one of the most fun restaurants in all of San Francisco, and has incredibly tasty food to boot. The amount of times I've been to Chubby Noodle Brunch is probably 20+ in my two years in San Francisco, and it simply never gets old. $40 per person for bottomless mimosas or sangria + food--this is an SF deal you simply can't beat. 

Second to the food is the atmosphere! At brunch they have mini yellow rubber ducks they put in your drinks and play nothing but '90s and 2000s rap music (yeah buddy!) While the space is small, it's always packed and the mood is usually very lively. 

NOTE: The dinner menu is different than the brunch menu. Brunch menu includes dumplings, pork buns, Asian porridge, and some other things you can't get at dinner. 

I've tried almost everything on the menu and these are a few of my favorite things (on the dinner menu... also sound of music puns) 

1) Salt and Pepper Shrimp-- 5/5 the best shrimp I've had, maybe ever. They give you either a spicy mayo dipping sauce or Thai peanut sauce.--I always go mayo. 

2) Pork Fried Rice--Always a yes. So tasty 

3) Spicy Garlic Noodles (I get with Shrimp or chicken but they let you add any meat for addition $$$)--So these I've had really spicy or not so much. You can request your desired level of spice, and either way they're always delicious. 

4) Green beans--I don't even like green beans that much but YUMMM do they put a delicious teriyaki sauce on them. A must-get in my opinion! Especially if you want to err on the side of healthy. 

5) Asian Fried Chicken--Basically boneless wings that you can dip in a spicy mayo dipping sauce, but they're amazing 

Things to Skip: 

Duck Lettuce wraps (duck is a bit too gamey) 
Poke (I've had better) 
Pad Thai (not the most flavorful) 
Asian bone-in chicken wings (not the most meat on their bone-in wings)
author: Liz S.

description:
Ambience and customer service was amazing! I had the pork tacos (not the biggest portion but DELICIOUS), while my girlfriend had the spicy garlic noodles (decent portion as noodles usually are, also amazing) 

We also had the "Girl can't take you nowhere" sake flight to round off the night. Everything came incredibly fast which always leaves a huge impression on a restaurant patron.

Pretty small and cute location on a busy-ish street. Definitely would visit again.
author: Tiger Y.

description:
Quite possibly my new favorite go-to restaurant in SF. I've been incessantly craving this place ever since I had the pleasure of consuming the spicy garlic noodles and chubby fried chicken, and based on the number of repeat visits I've already squeezed in, I can safely estimate that my cravings will never ever subside. 

Additional facts:
- The jalapeno calamari is also delicious, and apparently a hot commodity so get there early so you don't risk it being sold out
- Speaking of getting there early, get there early. This place is poppin' even on weeknights, so try and get a reservation or find a way to get there before 6PM for dinner. 
- Speaking of poppin', I can't believe I went 26 years without realizing that noodles and chicken taste infinitely better with hip hop and rap blasting in the background. Absolutely love the vibe.
author: Madhur B.

description: Mehhh.... if you want to sit in a bro scene then dine in. We ordered to go and I was unimpressed. This is my second time here (first time I felt the same way but wanted to give it another shot). Tastes like greasy Chinese food that I could get cheaper and better. Ordered the garlic chicken noodles, these weren't bad, greasy though. Ordered the salt and pepper shrimp and received a to go container half full of cold shrimp (tasted like had been sitting out all day, deep fried but soggy). Constantly crowded with the typical rowdy "marina crowd". I'll pass next time.
author: Kayli G.

description:
OK, it was Sunday night and we needed to eat an early dinner before heading out to the airport.  We had swung and missed for brunch at Honey Honey with our college going son so we didn't want to go 0-2. Chubby Noodle was a hit.  We had not had Szechuan green beans in a while and they were worth the wait. 

My son fancies himself an expert on fried rice given the number of times eaten.  When he orders it in a restaurant or for take out, it is always ordered with no peas or carrots.  To say he was excited when the dish showed up with neither would be an understatement. The pork was red, sweet and tender, the way it is supposed to be.  The rib appetizer fell off the bone the right way and had great seasoning.  The garlic noodles with the fried chicken added to it had the right blend of spice and crunch.  The Kobe beef noodles used a different noodle and sauce and was well worth the leftovers we sent him home with. 

All the food was served piping hot while the the dance music (too loud - nope) pumped bass into the place.  We will be back!
author: Ken R.

description:
Since we ordered take out from here, I believe Chubby Noodles deserves the good reviews. The food smelled so good when it arrived and was still pretty hot. We ordered the Kobe beef noodles, Korean tacos, and the chubby chicken. 

The chicken was so soft and tender and the sauce it came with seemed to pair well with it. The beef with the noodles was also so soft as well. It basically melted in your mouth. 

I would like to actually dine in here one day to taste the food fresh, but take out was still so good. 

I definitely recommend the noodles, especially since that word is in their restaurant name.
author: Allyson L.

description:
This place is a fun place for brunch and for bottomless food and drinks. It's a little pricey for me, but I guess near the average amount one would spend in the city (came out to be about $53 a person). 

We did the bottomless mimosas and dim sum on a Saturday morning. I made reservations for 10 am because my party was of 8 people. I highly recommend making reservations because they get very busy, very fast. Even though I got there at exactly 10 it was already getting pretty crowded. 

They have two servers going around, one for food and one for drinks. 

The food server was great. Since our party was so large, he asked if he could order the dishes for us and asked if there was anything in particular we wanted. I think the portions were a good size. Each plate wasn't an over-abundance of food, and one dish had enough for everyone to try. The food was very Americanized for being dim sum but we went in knowing that. With that being said, everything was decent in taste. My favorite dish was the garlic green beans. Most of the plates were also a little spicy. Personally I cannot handle spicy, but my party enjoyed it. 

My only complaint is regarding the refill of the drinks. We went there with high hopes of stacking up the rubber duckies that our drinks came with, but they were not given with our drink refills. The drink server kept saying he would come back with them but he didn't. It also took a little while for our drinks to be refilled. They were pretty busy so we tried to be understanding of the situation. 

I would probably still go back because it was filling and their pineapple mimosa was pretty good.
author: Melissa C.

description:
Great spot for brunch, brought out of town visitors and it was a great way to get our day started. I recommend making a reservation, because my group of 6 showed up at opening (10am) and the first available table wasn't until noon. 

It's all you can eat/drink for 90 minutes, and the wait staff keeps the food coming so you don't really have to order anything specific. That being said, if there is anything in particular that you ~don't~ want to eat, you can tell them in advance and they won't bring that to your table. The plates can run small, but you can reorder anything you liked. 

Food highlights: garlic and pepper shrimp (you're gonna want to order the sauce by the gallon), green beans, noodles.
Food to skip: Soup courses. The only liquids you should be consuming here are the bottomless mimosas/tea drinks.

Atmosphere: awesome loud pregame-y 90s/early 2000's music, but very crowded and hot inside. People dress trendy but with the amount of food you'll be consuming you're better off wearing stretchy pants.
author: Rachel K.

description:
I always love visiting San Fransisco. I went to Chubby Noodle based on the Yelp reviews and I was not disappointed in the slightest. I ordered the spicy garlic noodles and the salt and pepper shrimp. 

Let me just say that I still dream about the meal and if I lived in San Francisco, I'd be a regular there. 

The noodles weren't too overpowering with garlic, but they were creamy and the noodle texture was just right. The shrimp was bursting with juiciness and flavor, but the outside fried batter provided a good crispy texture. The shrimp was served with a light peanut sauce which was delightful. 
If I had to give constructive criticism, I'd say the music was a bit too loud for my liking. But it did add to the overall atmosphere. 

Highly recommend to anyone looking for some good Asian infusion food with good vibes!!
author: Susannah C.

description:
I made reservations over the phone for Chubby's bottomless dim sum brunch on a Sunday about two weeks in advance, and it's mandatory to put down your card to hold your reservation.

For $39 (basically $50 when you include tip) you have an hour and a half to order as many drinkz and brunch foods as you like. For drinks we mostly stuck to the mimosas and sangria, but personally I don't drink so the waiter was very kind to bring me a few glasses of their fresh squeezed OJ instead. 

I recommend coming here with a bigger group (minimum 4, but ideally 6) so you can try as many dishes as possible without getting full. My favorites were the breakfast jook (my friends who've never had jook before didn't like this at all, but this Asian girl loved it ¯\_(ツ)_/¯), pork buns, green beans (pleasantly salty sauce), and salt & pepper shrimp (came with a yummy aioli to dip in). Again definitely try as many items as you can, and you can order multiples of orders if you like them enough!

I've done Chubby brunch at this location and the North Beach location (both times with a group of 6), and slightly preferred the NB location. In the Marina, you sit on tall stools which can hurt after awhile, and I thought the NB location had a better ambiance overall.

While pricey, brunch at Chubby is definitely something all SF residents should try at least once!
author: Tracy C.

description: Chubby Noodle for brunch on a Saturday is a TIME. The most fun I've ever had at brunch. (If you're looking for a boozy brunch) It is yummy Chinese Food, and they blast hip hop and rap music. It's the best time ever.
author: Laura J.

description:
I can't trust other people's yelp reviews after this. I don't agree with a lot of these other reviews. I don't even think I have a super picky palate or anything but I just felt really deceived from the reviews. 

I went here for their weekend AYCE brunch on a Sunday with my boyfriend. We were really excited since this place seemed really cool. Who wouldn't get excited for AYCE/AYCD? It's AYCE dim sum in the sense that all the dishes come in small portions, and the drink selection included Sapporo beer, watermelon mimosas, sangria, and cold tea. It seems like a cool little hip place, and it seems cool to bring a bunch of your friends here to have a good time.

First off, I loved the idea of having unlimited drinks, and it made the price of $39/person slightly more agreeable. I got the mimosa and the combo with watermelon was gross. Sangria also wasn't great. They had plain watermelon juice if you wanted, but since it was the same (not fresh) watermelon juice used in the mimosa, NO THANK YOU. Just get the canned Sapporo if you were to come here (I hope you don't). 

The restaurant itself is pretty small. They play such a unique selection of music which you wouldn't hear at other lunch spots which I liked. However, it was just way too loud- I couldn't have a proper conversation since it was so difficult to talk over the music.

All the food on the menu (14 items) were foods I was interested in, but after trying almost all the items, all of them were honestly pretty bad. None of them were spectacular. They had a decent selection and all the food came out pretty fast, but all of the food was just that- subpar. 
-Roast duck buns: wasn't moist at all and the skin in most parts were hard to bite
-Pork won tons: the skin was super thick and the inside just tasted like gross meatballs
-Breakfast jook: I took a couple of sips but it was way too salty!!! It isn't even hard to make jook since it's a simple dish with simple ingredients.... 

The food that I would say was okay would just be the salt and pepper shrimp, chow mein, and shrimp fried rice. On the real though.... how would you mess these up, these are pretty standard dishes. 

Again, I've never been a super critical person when it comes to food. However, it just angered my boyfriend and I with how popular this spot is. The total came out to be around $106 for the two of us. I also didn't like how they automatically charged us for 20% tip for our small party. I would much rather go to a nice dim sum place (or even anywhere else) and get a decent amount of quality food for this price or even less! 

Restaurant had a good concept, but everything was not executed well.
author: Sydney E.

description:
Came for my friend's boozy birthday brunch on Saturday in a group of 12 girls and had a blast. Our reservation started right when they opened and went for about 1h30, so we knew that was our full time frame to all-we-could-eat-and-drink. Let me say the sangria is addicting, and the food is good. Not everything is a slam dunk (not everyone wants to eat green beans first thing in the morning) but for the most part, if you like asian food, it's super good and you'll leave feeling very full and very happy.

I think the best part is the ambiance, especially if you're there with a big group. They play lots of fun/loud music, and the people who work there are generally young and know you're there to have a good time and want to help you do that. We were dancing in our seats by dish 3, and they were 0% surprised by that and 100% accommodating. They provided us with several rubber ducks.

Only surprising thing I'll point out about Chubby Noodle is that it's quite small and has one bathroom. I wouldn't be surprised if the place expanded in the next 6 months to a year!
author: Katie K.

description:
Chubby Noodle is the best place you could possibly find for loud, celebratory, large group brunching.

Bottomless dim sum and drinks brunch is $37/person (basically a flat $50 with tax and tip) and lasts for 1.5 hours. There's something for everyone here--from green beans to pork wontons and chicken chow mein. My group of 11 opted to try everything on the menu, and my personal favorite dish was the salt and pepper shrimp. While nothing in particular tasted particularly authentic (but let's be real--this is a loud, hip-hop blasting brunch spot in the Marina, so let's be realistic about our expectations), you can't go wrong with perfectly fried shrimp dipped in an addictive aioli. Breakfast jook comes for a close second, though this one might only be appealing for people who are familiar with East Asian porridge.

Would I actively choose to come back? No. But I think my return is probably inevitable, and I have to admit Chubby Noodle is pretty great for what it is (again, the perfect spot for loud, celebratory group brunching). So here's to you, Chubby Noodle, and the massive food coma and headache you gave me. 4 stars.
author: Kelly R.

description: The food here was good, not amazing, but tasty and well priced. Service was friendly. Space super cramped and difficult to place even 2 orders of food on the table. The place needs a thorough cleaning, some temperature controls and maybe a dress code for the workers. Oh, and a less offensive hand washing sign in the bathroom--which also needs a few gallons of bleach. We sat in the window where I had a view of kitchen supplies, a very dirty swath of fabric on the wall coated in grease and dust, and servers wearing outfits that featured their underwear. We made reservations because I had come before and there was a line out the door, and for such a slap shot place--I didn't expect to have to confirm with a credit card and receive 3 reminders about our table. I'd skip this place and go somewhere cleaner and quieter.
author: Maria R.

description: It is a fun and trendy experience if you are looking for a good time. Granted there is better Asian food if you venture out to the inner Richmond or sunset, however Chubby Noodle isn't bad for being in the Marina. We paid 50 bucks each and got bottomless and a ton of food for 90 minutes. I am Asian, and this was my first time to this location and I was much more impressed with the food than the north beach location. Anyways, fun for birthdays, or if you are looking to get wild!
author: Ross S.

description: This street food spot has fantastic garlic noodles that stay with you long after you finish, to the consternation of your companions ;) I also enjoyed the pork fried rice with and egg which was far bigger than I expected with big chunks of savory pork. Price could have been lower but is ok for SF.
author: Benjamin S.

description:
Went here on a whim, trying to find some place to save us from the rain. Its a small, somewhat cozy spot with kind of a date night ambiance, and hipster vibe. 

The menu is short, and many items are limited and some sold out by the time we got there, around 7-8pm.

It can get pricey for the portions you get but the flavors are just perfect! 

The spicy garlic noodles, jalepeño calamari, and salmon sashimi were sooo good! 

The short ribs were a miss, so sad. 
I tried their alcoholic lemonade, but it wasn't that great.

I've already come back for the noodles and calamari to-go, and they were even better and I believe bigger portions. I'm sure I'll come back again for take out.
author: Gabriela M.

description:
I have been here 3 times so far, but after this last visit (on 2/3) I'm not sure I feel like going back again.

The food is amazing everything is fried perfectly and the sauces that come with everything compliment the food very well. The spicy garlic noodles were definitely a favorite so props to the kitchen staff.

I have 2 reasons for giving it 3 stars.
