The first was the music, the type of music was great but it was just straight up too loud. I spent the whole time there shouting to my friends sitting at the same table. This restaurant is definitely not a "cozy spot with kind of a date night ambiance" as other reviewers put it.

And it seems like as a result of the blasting music some of the people that have started to come here treat the fucking place like its a frat house.

The 2nd reason was the service, it wasn't bad but they made a few mistakes over the course of the night and didn't really attempt to fire off our food at good intervals. It all just came at the same time and we didn't have any space left on the table.
author: Mario M.

description:
4-stars mainly because our waiter, Mark (Marc) was literally so sweet and the best! The drinks were good and consistently filled, and the food was pretty good. $39 (not including tip or tax) for "AYCE" dimsum and drinks! It wounded up being about $54 per person which was pretty pricy, but something I'm willing to spend for special occasions once in a while. Definitely think its a little over priced for how the system works but I'm not complaining too much. 

We had come here for a friend's birthday with a party of 8 and a reservation and were seated promptly in a poppin, yet small, restaurant area. The music is modern, the ambience super fun and turnt, and the restaurant itself clean! It was super packed when we got there at 2PM, and although they close at 2:30, they technically close the doors at 2:30 and allow everyone to stay the 90 minutes that each session is allowed. They brought out food pretty consistently and enough for our 8-person party, but also made sure to take our orders into mind if we had a specific item on the menu we wanted to try. The food itself was honestly pretty good! The pork buns were so full of meat, the wings were pretty good, noodles tasty, and soup was filling. It's honestly super expensive, but we all got super full and pretty turnt, but still regulated (they refill your drinks for you on a basis of coming around to your table).
author: Briana N.

description:
Food, music, and service is fantastic and will provide you with a unique experience.

Although the wait was a little long (~30-45 mins), it was definitely worth the wait. Plus, you can explore all of the neat venues around the area. The waiter/waitresses were extremely friendly and personable. Being our first time there, they took their time to explain their menu and make genuine suggestions. What surprised me was their music. I'm certain most people will be following their 'fire' playlist after. 

The only cons are the PRICE and LIGHTING. It can be a little expensive, however it's totally worth it. GET THE PORK RIBS AND TACOS! Lastly, it is dim and some people like myself can't see that well haha.
author: Pele L.

description:
Man is this place busy on a Sunday morning! Apparently you need to have a reservation or else try again another day. Came in with a friend and we did the $39 deal they had. They give you EVERYTHING that's on the menu and it includes bottomless mimosas!

Food was delicious. They had hip hop music playing and it gets you in the right mood especially when you're pounding down mimosas. Extremely small and quaint but it works for a place like this. 

Also, they also have a second location in North Beach which isn't as busy so if you just want to enjoy the food without the busyness of the original location then I suggest you stop by that one. 

Would I be back? Most definitely!
author: Michael T.

description: DELICIOUS!! I ordered way too much food and still managed to finish all of it because I could not put my fork down.  The winners: Garlic Noodles and the Green beans
author: Run.It.Off V.

description:
Snarky service for my first time being here. Super ratchet trap music blasting and full of typical absent minded "marina crowd". Hostess mentioned she's not from "here" (SF). 

They have time sessions in which they reset tables for the AYCE & Drink. Be sure to only come for reservations or during the flip sessions if you want a spot during the weekend. 

If you want to be surrounded by all the typical/stereotypical culture that gives the Marina it's bad reputation, then this is your place. 

Solution: new management, different atmosphere (would lead to less drunk people acting up)
author: Mike G.

description: Have eaten here a few time.  Loved the kale salad with chicken and the pork tacos.  Really good quality and flavor.
author: J C.

description:
Maybe named Chubby Noodle because the noodles are so good, you'll probably pack on a few pounds during your visit? 

I loved my multiple visits to Chubby Noodles because everything was so delicious - especially, the garlic noodles! 

This place is always hot and packed - be sure to arrive at a decently early or late hour to not have to stand in line too long (I don't think they take reservations or maybe I waited because I never made reservations, I can't remember). 

Anyway, garlic noodles and sake are a must! Enjoy!
author: Irina R.

description:
It's okay, but if I'm in North Beach there are plenty of places I'd prefer over this. First, I think brunch here is way more popular, but i came here for dinner. They don't have watermelon mimosas for dinner! I also have an egg allergy so I could not eat the dishes with egg noodles (which is large amount of menu) and they would not sub for a different noodle (even tho they have rice noodle and sweet potato on menu). I thought that was odd.

The food was kinda greasy and mostly fried.. it was still decent but it is just bar food, and for that it is far too expensive. I came here with a friend and we had a lot to catch up on, but this is definitely a place where they want to rush you out. I get that they are busy, but I felt pretty rushed through my meal. For dinner I'd pass coming here, and in general I'm kind of a slow eater so I don't know if I'd want to try out the ever-popular brunch menu either.
author: Mariam P.

description:
I like loud music, loud hip-hop music, especially. 
I also like Asian food, and fusion is also usually something I'd love to try. 

Not sure I like those items combined though. The music was very loud, and while the food was flavorful, our noodles were a bit overcooked. The tacos were pretty decent, but Kogi does this better and is much cheaper. 

I have to say it's not quite what I was expecting given the prices. I get it, San Francisco is an expensive city - and this is one of the more expensive neighborhoods there. But in a way that makes it worse - a room full of well-heeled white people listening to loud (uncensored) hip-hop while eating slightly above-average Asian fusion is not really my idea of a great time. 

I'd be willing to try the place again if I am in the area though.
author: Michael G.

description:
I want to give 5 stars to this place because the food is SO GOOD.  But I have to bring it down two stars due to the deafening music blasting the entire time.  I had to walk about half a block down the street to watch a video on my phone (full volume) while I waited for my friends to show up.  Maybe the music is turned up to deafen you to heighten your other senses (read: taste) so you think the food is better.  

That being said, I wouldn't know if there was good service or not because I couldn't hear anything being said to me by the server.
author: Celine C.

description:
Absolutely the best brunch spot in the city. Great food, great service, and an amazing vibe. 

The food is all served family style. I usually go with a big group of people, so what the waiter does is plan out the menu for us. We can put in requests if we want more of something but otherwise the food keeps coming out every few minutes and you get to sample a little bit of everything. 

The drinks are bottomless and I would definitely recommend the cold tea. It is a wine cocktail that's really light (not on the alcohol) and isn't too sweet. They have a different special mimosa every week. 

A few things you HAVE to try if you're here: salt and pepper shrimp, green beans, breakfast juk, and Peking duck. 

It's on the pricey side (it's exactly $53.22 a person w/ tax and gratuity included) but both the food and drinks are bottomless so it's well worth it.
author: Nick D.

description:
The textures, the flavors, the presentation, the service, the cooking are all reasons to come here and order everything and share it. In order of favoriteness I offer you this list.

Korean tacos
Spicy garlic noodles
Duck lettuce wraps
Jalapeno calamari (sauce is like angel tears if you're into that kind of thing)
Kimchi
Curry lemongrass vermicelli
Pork ribs
Kobe beef chow mein
author: Marissa N.

description:
Came here on a Sunday. LATE! I almost thought they wouldn't let us sit. It closes at 11 and we walked in like 20 min before closing time. Our server was so sweet I wish I remembered her name! 
We got the garlic noodles, and the salt and pepper shrimp. Sooooo good! Especially the shrimp and the sauce it came with! 
Also they were BUMPIN' in there lol all the middle school dance hip hop jams, it was great lol.
author: Cristina G.

description:
My first time here, and I visited on the recommendation of my daughter. The first thing I noticed was that it seemed like everyone in the place was about 30 years or younger, just a observation. The second thing I noticed was that they had the 90's & 2k hip-hop Playlist going (which I liked BTW). 

Now onto the food and service. Seating is very cramped, and wait times are at least 20 minutes, so keep that in mind. I ordered the Koby beef chow mein. It was good, but a little different than I was used to. The noodles  are more on the thin side (vermacelli?). Like I said though, the taste was very good. 

Down playing the good food, was that it took nearly 30 minutes for our noodles to arrive, and when they did, they got one of the plates wrong. I'll try again one more time on a less busy day before giving a final verdict.
author: Mark R.

description: One of those restaurants that cement's San Francisco's reputation as a destination for Asian cuisine. Everything on the menu was delicious and waitstaff were pleasant.
author: Tim O.

description: One of the best tasting restaurants I've ever been too! I would HIGHLY recommend coming here! We had the papaya salad, kale salad (with avocado, apple, macadamia nuts), pork tacos, curry vermicelli, garlic noodles with fried chicken, and jalapeño calamari. I would order everything all over again, except maybe for the papaya salad. The papaya salad was delicious, but the other ones were even more so. I would highly recommend the kale salad, curry vermicelli, and jalapeño calamari. Gosh they were so delicious, I wish I was writing this review while at the restaurant eating them, haha. There was a service mishap, but the waiter took care of it above and beyond our expectations and was so, so accommodating. Great and quick service. Went there on a Monday night and only had to wait 5 minutes for a table. Please do yourself a favor and go eat dinner here!
author: Li W.

description: Yummy yummy great place to eat. Very spacious good vibe, pretty cool music playing! We ordered the chicken with the dipping sauce yummy, we ordered the pork tacos yummy, we had the shrimp pad thai awesome and a few glasses of white wine!
author: Karen F.

description: Super tasty and really fun. Definitely would recommend coming w a group for brunch and doing bottomless. It never disappoints.
author: Gianna M.

description:
I gotta tell ya, I'm a fan of Chubby Noodle. Like, a big fan. It's a great concept with a limited menu and plenty of flavorful options. Really though, the flavors coming out of the kitchen are really good! My suggestion... avoid the health warning pop up when looking into this place because it's worth the "risk".

In my most recent visit (I've been numerous times), I had the following: 

- Pad Thai - solid. not my favorite of the bunch but, nice to have a noodle on board. I think the garlic noodles are a superior order.
- Papaya Salad - also a bit underwhelming but, it was nice to have some freshness in the meal. 
- Pork Tacos - I mean, these are probably the best thing on the menu. Without a doubt. 
- Spicy Wings - A very close second and a must order for anyone that's a fan of wings. 

Amongst all of this, my friend and I misheard the server and ordered 1L of house sake which was more than sufficient for the two of us. Seriously, it's a lot of sake for two. We didn't finish it (thank god) and gave it to our friendly neighbors :)

Our server that evening was more than attentive but, not overwhelming. Service, an easy 5 stars...no doubt.
author: Benjamin F.

description: Enjoyed the food and the atmosphere! They were jamming Cardi B.! It's loud and had good energy because the kitchen is partially open. Food I had: green beans (tastey), Korean pork tacos (really tastey), kun Pao wings (good), fried chicken (good, but definitely needed the dipping sauce, otherwise they would be super basic), garlic noodles (these were okay and a little bland,  I was expecting a lot more given that the restaurant is named 'Chubby Noodle').  I also tasted their housemade kimchi. It was a very "fresh" kimchi, not funky or spicy and again, a little blander than I'm used to. I Love kimchi so maybe I'm just picky. I dont venture to the Marina for food very often so I'm really glad I came here. I would definitely recommend this place for a fun group dinner or casual date.
author: Zoey M.

description: Awesome food awesome service . Spicy noodles add pork and tacos are best . Love fried chicken and ahi tuna as well.
author: Lindsay S.

description: Came by Saturday night with no wait, it was blasting loud rap music and smelling delicious! We got garlic noodles (of course) and Korean pork tacos - both of which are tasty but pretty expensive compared to other places in other districts. $12 noodles with $5 shrimp add in, and $12 for two tacos. I hear the Star is really dim sum brunch so I'll have to come back here in the future!
author: Wendy L.

description:
The atmosphere here is great - loud and fun - but the food was not at all to my taste. I ordered Pad Thai and a side of cucumbers and sesame. The cucumbers were refreshing but very sweet when they should have been sharp. 

The Pad Thai was disgusting for want of a better word. It was a sickly sweet and syrupy affair which even a squeeze of lime couldn't cut. Its taste bore no resemblance to anything I've had either in Thailand or in any Thai restaurant. It seemed to be catering to people who want sugar laden food exclusively, whether it's entree or dessert. 

The white wine (no choice) was a Chilean Sauvignon which was surprisingly good but it was killed by the arrival of the syrupy mush. 

They claim that there is free wifi but it's not true. You have to sign up through Facebook and like them.
author: Norman B.

description: Their spicy garlic noodle with chicken is amazing! It's not very spicy so ask for extra sauce!
author: Harshita S.

description:
Had a brunch reservation for 11 on a Sunday morning at 10am. 

Incredible service--very welcoming staff that take care of you from start to finish with both food and drinks constantly flowing. Marco in particular made sure that our glasses were never too empty, and if they were he was quick and funny to refill them with a smile. 

I was a little worried that this establishment was among those that take forever to bring food out, and while we did have to wait about 12-15 minutes upon sitting down for any plates to arrive (your 1.5 hr limit begins as soon as you sit), everyone left stuffed and happy with our food options, pescatarian included. The food itself is not necessarily mindblowing, but it's all delicious. There are a few dishes like the kimchi/cucumbers and bok choy/mushrooms that are pretty meh in comparison to the yummier dishes like the pork buns and salt and pepper shrimp, but it's very easy to request more of what you want more rounds of. 

The loud atmosphere can take away, but you're coming here for drinks, food, and a good time, so you're bound to get a little loud and the music helps you get into the mood.  

While the $50+ tag (we ordered sake shooters) is definitely steep, my friends and I had a fantastic time and are planning to come back again!
author: Annamarie S.

description:
The hip hip/rap jams mixed with "ayce" dim sum and bottomless drinks had me milly rockin' throughout my meal. I could hear their music from down the street and was surprised to believe how the ambiance catered to a younger crowd. 

My friend and I came in an hour before they closed and the waiter brought up that they have a 90 min table limit, but since we only had an hour left.. He was willing to charge us $28 opposed to the full price of $37. Bless his heart. My friend and I were more excited for the bottomless mimosas + sangria so we just told our waiter to take the initiative to order food for us. We did not want to waste any time. 

With a 60 min window to eat, I found myself devouring everything in sight.. No ragrets. Here's how it works: you choose 15 dim sum items and 4 alcoholic drinks. The servers were kind enough to keep the drinks comin' and basically just ended up giving us a pitcher of mimosa with a couple complimentary sake shooters. I love everyone here.. From what I remember, the top 3 dishes that I really enjoyed were: the shanghai dumplings, salt & pepper shrimp, green beans. But, you really can't go wrong with ordering everything. 
 
I will def keep coming back here, not only for the delicious food, but also the welcoming people and lit ass atmosphere.
author: Rachelle Y.

description: These are the best noodles I have ever had. When in San Francisco you have to go here. I had the garlic spicy noodles with big pork it was awesome.  And the Kung pao wings OMG!!!!
author: Jeffrey B.

description: BEST jalepeño garlic noodles and pork fried rice EVER! Korean pork tacos are also bomb, it's hard to go wrong.
author: Alex A.

description:
Came for brunch and this was my first experience here. The service was very friendly and helpful. The food was delicious. The tables are extremely small and the dishes needed to be bussed a little more often tho.

I really enjoyed the green beans, pork buns and jook. They blast hip hop so it's definitely a lively brunch scene. I left stuffed and thankful. We'll be back.
author: Leilani B.

description:
I have to admit that, while I was super skeptical about CN at first, the food and overall experience converted me into a believer. 

I'm usually not one to groan about the bastardization of Asian culture, nor have I ever been called a food purist towards any kind of cuisine, but when I saw ceviche, ramen, chow mien, and tacos all listed on one menu AND "served tapas style," I thought "Oh HELL naw. This is going to be the Marina/Bro version of PF Changs." Well, stupid me for thinking that- this place served up several delicious dishes and they all tasted pretty damn authentic! 

We were in a large group and got to try a bit of everything, from the salmon to many types of noodles, delicious chicken wings, calamari, and a few others that I forgot about thanks to their delicious soju killing those brain cells.

We politely stacked all of our dishes and chopsticks which, for some reason, really surprised the waitress. Supposedly the basic bros of the area do no such thing. Instead, many bro shenanigans are usually had. She gave us a couple shots of sake for it, which also made me really happy about the overall experience. 

The slightly higher prices, limited space, and long wait times were each a little pesky, but this was overall a 5/5 for flavor, service, 90's music, and opening my mind a bit! Thanks for making me a believer, CN!
author: Stephen D.

description:
Location: Street parking available away from Lombard and limited seating. The interior is cool and the music is always poppin'. 

Service: Servers are very attentive, helpful, and quick. 

Food: 
-Spicy garlic noodles (5/5): we got 2 of these; one with fried chicken and one with prawns. Both were amazing - tons of garlic and noodles were cooked to perfection. 
-Lemongrass chicken vermicelli (4/5): this seemed like one of the healthier dishes (aka fresh vegetables) so it was a perfect dish to cleanse our palates 
-Korean pork tacos (5/5): seriously delicious - these are overflowing with the filling. An order comes with 2 - but if you come with an odd amount of people they can give that to you too. 
-Kung pao wings (3/5): I'm not a huge wings person - but these were still really good. Hot, sticky, and sweet. 
-Chubby fried chicken (5/5): LOVE! Little fried chicken chunks that taste great with the sauce. 

I just wish this location was open for lunch, since I work just a few blocks away..
author: Shelley K.

description:
Service and Food was good, but this is a terrible venue for groups. Aside from being really cramped, like can't-use-chopsticks-without-bumping-neighbor-no-room-for-plates-cramped, it's extremely loud so you can't hear each other talk, which definitely took away from the occasion. Mind you, I am under 30 so hearing is typically not an issue. To be fair we were seating directly under the speaker. Music was good though!

The food was delicious and they did a good job of keeping it coming during our 90 minute all-you-can-eat/drink window. Service was friendly. Drinks were not that great, but you shouldn't expect more at an all-you-can-eat place anyways.

I would definitely go back again but not with a large group.
author: Ali S.

description: Cannot say enough good things about the AYCE brunch! Delicious!  I love to see the young people enjoying themselves there, and enjoyed going twice with my daughter ! I love the pork buns and the little ducks fit the drinks!
author: Ann M.

description:
First and forth most --awesome customer service

Props to the hostess, waitress, waiter and clean up crew.

They were very prompt and made sure our drinks were filled and empty plates were out of our way.

Four of us enjoyed our AYCE brunch. And I'm still craving for the Hoang mimosa. So good and refreshing

At $28 (we paid less cause we decided to stay only an hr vs. $37 for 90 mins).

My fav:

Chicken noodles
Jook!! Jook!!!
Pork buns
Cold ramen
String beans

Disliked:
Wontons
Chicken wings
Salad
Duck--too dry 

everything was good including fried rice. 

Atmosphere:
Small restaurant
Open kitchen
Bar seating
Booth seating
Music was way too loud though :(
People tend to get louder when they had or have their three drinks! Haha
I'm Chinese and it's weird to see Mexicans cooking (nothing wrong with that) but they did a great job representing and cooking Chinese food!

But nevertheless it was fun and will definitely come back again

Thanks chubby noodle!

Total bill- $37 with tips and tax
author: Carol Y.

description:
0/10
- worst restaurant in sf by a large margin (that includes fast food). 
- scammy descriptions (peking duck is an embarrassment + isn't peking duck, dan dan noodles aren't dan dan noodles, pork wontons worse than ling ling frozen dumplings)
- garbage taste
- i still want my money back
- bottomless mimosas, fancy annoying waiters, so i guess its a good spot for arguing over blockchains / geeking out about tech
author: Yuen Hsi C.

description: Its tasty. But its also pretty mediocre food. This fare of food is everywhere now and this is nothing special. The raw salmon we got was on point. incredible freshness. the rest was good, but nothing special at all and for SF I was expecting more.
author: Alex S.

description:
Absolutely one of my favorite brunch spots! If you like Asian food and are down for all you can eat/all you can drink for around $40 per person this is the place for you. 

I recommend the shrimp, chubby noodle chow mein, green beans, pork steamed buns, king Poe wings, and breakfast jook. 

The cold iced tea is good (sake, midori, and iced tea) and strong. And the servers are great, but very busy.
author: Elena K.

description:
Shove a loaf of butter up your ass and pucker up to carefully extrude it into a long, thin strand. Place this into a bowl, smother it in cheap, completely artificial soy sauce and stale, rancid sesame seeds and you'll have something that is healthier, tastier and demonstrably less offensive than whatever the fuck kind of bullshit sellout "Asian fusion" it is they pretend to produce in the Chubby Noodle kitchen. 

Their website begs the question "What better way to eat noodles than with R. Kelly singing in the background?" and I think it would be better if R. Kelly was physically present to piss in the mouths of all their frat boy finance bro customers' right there in the foreground because that would be far less nauseating to behold than the greasy, amateurish offerings of whatever serial entrepreneur went and found himself a handy banana puppet to profit off of in the neighborhood culture forgot.
author: Nicholas J.

description: Food was good, drinks were meh. Would come back again and get there a little early because they will start your 2 hour limit whether you're there or not.
author: Tara K.

description: This place is a gem. The atmosphere is casual and fun. It is dark inside and there is usually loud hip hop music playing the background which I like, but I could see how some people might not. We love the szechuan green beans, chubby friend chicken, and spicy garlic noodles. You can make reservations but I've never had a problem finding a table for 2 during peak hours. The service is great and the waiters are always attentive.
author: Emily M.

description:
I've been hearing about this brunch place for years and went here in August for my friends birthday. 

Since reservations were made in advance, we were seated fairly quickly. However, seating for a table of six at the booth was a tight squeeze but we managed. 

Immediately our server came by to introduce himself and explained how the menu worked. We explained we wanted one of everything and to make sure my one friend got some vegetarian items. Shortly after he then had someone come over to take our drink orders.

As I was waiting, I took a sip of my water cup, only to see murky residue in the cup (looked like oil from food). I was pretty appalled by a glass cup that was so dirty.

We waited for a solid 15-20 minutes for our first plate to come out. Keep in mind, we had 6 people at the table sharing small plates. My vegetarian friend didn't get her food until 15 minutes after we got our plate.

Though the service was great and the food was OK, at the end of the day, I walked out paying around $50/person, it was not worth it.
author: Anna H.

description:
While in town, I stopped in at Chubby Noodle for Sunday brunch-bottomless food and drinks for 90 mins. It was fun to eat on Lombard in the Marina district (not to be confused with their other location) with some girlfriends I was excited to catch up with. However the extremely loud music was a huge turn off, and I would not recommend eating here if you want a nice catch up session with your party- you'll be frustrated to not hear what they are saying, and leave with a horse voice from all the yelling. I appreciate that C.N. wants to make it a fun atmosphere, but turning the music down a few decibels would probably benefit all without ruining the "cool" vibe. 

A few tips for brunch- Your time starts when the reservations starts, and they wont seat you without your party so make sure slow Susie knows to hurry her butt up and not be late as she usually is- she'll waste some of your precious eating and drinking time. The drinks flow at a normal pace that the servers check on you, so that means ~4, unless you are aggressively flagging down the waitress. Their website and menu states they have the right to "slow your roll" on eating and drinking, so there's that as well!

Foodwise, I actually enjoyed most of the selections they brought out. They pretty much just pick what your table is going to get, and it is all served family style. The small tables are not the greatest to have a lot of plates with a larger party- there is simply not enough room. Be prepared to shovel food onto your small plate (and mouths) and try to get rid of the serving dish. Standout dishes to me were the green beans, fried chow mein, fried shrimp, and the peking duck with bun. For the 9 of us, we probably tried 10+ dishes...the food just kept coming. We had so much food we didn't end up re-ordering anything! 

The 90 mins passed in a flash and then we were kicked to the curb, tipsy and overly full. I think with proper expectations (not trying to meet with friends you haven't seen in years and yell over the music) Chubby Noodle is making fantastic food and I like the idea of AYCE drinks and food when the food is actually quality and not some buffet line of stale Chinese. Improvements for me would include softer music and more space for dining.
author: Lianna N.

description: Walnut shrimp were big and good but needed more walnuts.  Egg foo yung was great!  But sauce spilled all over in the delivery bag.  Ask for it separate if ordering delivery.  Black bean asparagus beef was good.  Pot stickers were thrown out - way too much dough.  They need a better bag for delivery so containers will stay flat and not slide to their side and spill.
author: Nancy J.

description:
Chubby Noodle's the spot! Fun and lively atmosphere for their weekend brunch. After 90 minutes of all you can eat/drink, you might need someone to roll you out of there. Tons of small plates and entrees to share, and great choices for drinks that they're always switching up. Service is always attentive and super friendly. 

They're also conveniently on Caviar, so late nights with no motivation to cook are solved! BBQ pork fried rice, cucumber salad, fried chicken: always ridiculously good.

Okay, also... salt and pepper shrimp and the spicy garlic noodles are unreal.
author: Bridget C.

description:
Chubby Noodle's weekend AYCE/AYCD brunch is the perfect activity if you wake up and decide you want to have an absolutely unproductive day. 

Arrive hungry and arrive thirsty. My typical go-to order when I sit down is to ask for them to bring out one of everything on their menu. There is no shame in having a bottomless stomach to match their bottomless brunch. The servers have always been great at bringing out a comprehensive selection of dishes and eliminating ones that are too similar. Very tapas style, so great for big groups. 

Personal favorites:
* Peking duck steam buns
* Breakfast jook
* Chilled ramen
* Garlic green beans

Aside from Chubby Noodle's delicious plates and energetic morning vibes, they also offer a fun element: they serve each brunch drink with a mini rubber ducky floating amongst the ice cubes. Initial reactions of delight at these kooky looking fellas quickly spiral into a dangerous game of "COLLECT ALL THE DUCKS!!" and before you know it, you are walking out with a pocketful of neon yellow birds and an acknowledgement that nothing useful will be achieved for the rest of the day (refer to said unproductive day above).
author: Jenni H.

description:
Came here to cure a hang over from the night before. They are close by and they have porridge, perfect for hang overs. But didn't realize they were only serving brunch and its all you can eat Chinese food! **Brunch = all you can eat and drink for $37 per person. Mix & match 15 dim sum items for 90 minutes. Did not have high exceptions because how good can Chinese food be in the Marina?! Well, little did I know, it was actually pretty good and very tasty. 

Bottomless Drinks - **COLD TEA is japaness sake with juice. **MIMOSA is with sparkling wine and juice. **SANGRIA is wine and juice. **ALL DRINKS served rubber duckies!! So CUTE. I Prefer the sangria over all the other drinks because I think it has the least amount of alcohol in it. Was still battling my hang over. 

My favorites are the **BREAKFAST JOOK. Jook served with over easy egg and BACON!! So freaken delicious! My other favorite is their **KUNG PAO WINGS. very flavorful. With a hint of spice. yum! Everything was good from the **CHUBBY CHICKEN CHOW MEIN (very tasty) to the **SHANGHAI DUMPLINGS. FYI, its not the soup dumplings. You would assume that shanghai dumplings are soup but they are not. They are buns, steam buns bbq chicken. Don't get me wrong, it was good but it wasn't soup dumplings. 

I think they only dish I would want to say I didn't like as much is the **PEKING DUCK STEAM BUNS. The steam buns was very good, soft and hot but the duck itself was not cut to serve for peking duck dish. Also the duck was a bit dry. 

My friend and I wanted to try everything but it was only the two of us. Can't wait to bring back more friends.
author: Sandy B.

description: We were visiting and unsure of where to eat. Chubby Noodle showed up as an option and we were not let down! Amazing atmosphere and excellent service. The server suggested too dishes and they were all win wins! Recommend for anyone in the area
author: Carla M.

description: Great noodle place. We had the kale salad with shrimp, the korean pork tacos, and the kobe beef chow mein, and that was a good amount of food for 2 people to split. The food was super tasty, and they have a great beer and sake selection. If you want to dodge the line, go around 5:30, otherwise be ready to wait 45-60 minutes. The reason I'm leaving a 4-star review is that the place isn't super well ventilated, so when they throw some noods on the grill, it gets real smoky. If they fixed their ventilation, it'd be a 5/5!
author: Phil Y.

description: The Korean pork tacos here are to die for! We also got the duck lettuce wraps (pretty darn good) and the BBQ pork fried rice (good, but nothing to write home about). The place was super noisy and crowded - but given that it was 9 pm on a Friday night I expected nothing less. We sat at the bar and the service was pretty quick.
author: Sam M.

description:
Solid choice for a raucous time - old school hip hop included!

They feature bottomless drinks & dim sum so everyone could enjoy a little bit of everything. 

It was a little hot & tight since I was sitting right by the kitchen area, but the rubber ducks in the drinks are a nice touch!
author: Roger D.

description:
This place is FIRE! Don't expect 'authentic' (whatever that may be haha), but certainly is tasty high quality food.

The atmosphere screams Marina bar scene (-1 star for aggressive rap on all nights). It would be nice to have a more cozy atmosphere on Sun. - Weds., but its their vibe so oh well!

The food was all standouts:
Salt & Pepper shrimp (soo fire, put the sauce on everything!)
Garlic noodles (nice and al dente)
Green Beans
Kung Pao Wings (tasty, but not crunchy enough)

Looking forward to trying more of their dishes! I certainly know what to expect now, and if I am looking for a more relaxed atmosphere, to order delivery ;)
author: Nathan L.

description: Best brunch spot in the marina. Best customer service and food is delicious. Ask for mark on the weekends he always takes good care of us.
author: Jonathon M.

description:
I don't get the good reviews.  The food here is very average..greasy and heavy.  I had the curry lemongrass vermicelli dish and the kale salad.  They have a bunch of tea pots at the entrance of the place, but don't serve hot tea.    It's loud in here...obnoxiously loud.  They're playing rap music that is chock full of expletives.  Classy.  

If you like sitting in smoke from the kitchen, and trying to have a conversation over very loud music, then come here.  I guess if you're getting drunk on their sake or cocktails then you won't care and will want greasy food.     I was not impressed.

Also.. I'm adding a note to my restaurant reviews about serving food.  Many restaurants don't train their staff not to cup or grip plates and bowls with their fingers..which results in the server's fingers being less than an inch proximity to your food, or in your food.  Try not to think about when they used the bathroom and if washed their hands or not.  There is a way to serve without gripping fingers over the edge of a bowl.
author: Wendy W.

description: This place has delicious food... try the green beans, tuna poke bowl and the spicy garlic noodles with fried chicken.
author: Andres S.

description: My 5 friends and I were put into a booth that is more suited for a party of five. We were told to move from a bigger table to a smaller table because of a party of 7 behind us in line. Food was delicious, but we felt rushed to eat quickly. Because the table was so crowded, we were pretty much eating in our laps. Getting our drinks refilled was difficult. The atmosphere was fun, with 90s rap music playing, but obviously what you pay for more than the quality of food and service.
author: Samantha E.

description: Hubby and I strolled to the Presidio spontaneously and after drove here for a meal.  We got here and according to hours, they were open, however, they were closed to the public due to a private event.  Hmm. Luckily for us, the event was ending in 45 min.  We waited it out.  Candidly, I wish we were there for AYCE.  But we weren't.  I loved their tacos, buuuuuut way over priced for 2!  I can speak for their noodles.  They are good.  Actually, probably the best thing we had there.  Service and staff was friendly, quick and nice.  Ambiance is what you expect.  I like the window seating, doesn't bother me, and you get to people watch a little.  I will say that their music is blasting, for the early dinner we were having, it didn't match the feel.  It can probably have a softer touch to it.  Music had some profanity, not sure if that is family friendly, but hey! It does cater to the "younger" crowd.  I'd like to come back and try the AYCE on the weekends and update my review.  Maybe someday in the near future.
author: Viclaire S.

description: This place has loud music and drunk people taking shots. It's more like a club environment (all about loud music, booze, drunk people) that serves food. I don't know about the food, because we put our name to wait for about 15 mins but left before because it was just too loud and we just wanted a relaxing dinner. I guess it's a good place to pre party and I guess that's why they have good reviews! Not my type of place anymore
author: J. S.

description: Went here for a friend's birthday party. The food was mediocre, not bad but not great and definitely not worth how loud and cramped it was. We had a party of 8 and we were very close to each other and we still had to shout just to decide what to order. If you want to go somewhere where you cannot hear anyone else, this is the place for you. Also if you like to be sardined in with strangers, you've found your ideal atmosphere here.
author: Tatiana S.

description: I just love this restaurant!  Their garlic noodles are superb!!!   Pretty much all their items are way above average!
author: Jerry W.

description:
This is the worst, most scarring experience I've ever had at a restaurant. I didn't even get to try the food, though it doesn't look very special.

Chubby Noodle needs to be better at managing expectations with walk-in reservations. We went on a Sunday at around noon to see if we could get a seat. I understand that the weekend is difficult because of the brunch rush (most of the restaurant is reserved for large groups), but if you know you can't seat us, JUST TELL US AND WE WILL GO SOMEWHERE ELSE. When we arrived, they told us they could probably seat us in 45 minutes and would call us around then. We walked around Lombard Street for an hour without hearing back and called to inquire about getting a table. They said they could probably accommodate us in around 30 more minutes. 

After 30 more minutes, we walked back. They told us 20 more minutes - just wait 20 more minutes. After 20 more minutes, they said to wait for their 2:00 PM seating even though they couldn't guarantee a seat, and you know what, actually, it was unlikely we would get a seat, sorry. But they did recommend for a tequila brunch bar down the street and to tell the restaurant we sent them! The host could not care less and gave me a warm smile as we walked out. At 2:30 PM, almost 2.5 hours after we had arrived, we decided to go to the Dorian instead (which was great, for the record).

Chubby Noodle isn't worth any of your time or money. Move on and don't look back!
author: K S.

description:
The wife and I squeezed in at the bar area right away, which is right by the entrance and less than ideal. But SO glad we saw it through. 

I got the cocktail that featured jalapenos, sake, basil, and lemonade. It was absolutely balanced and delicious. The pork tacos were to die for - don't miss them for anything. 

The small plates are a humanely sized for a light dinner. Prices are reasonable if you're prepared for quality over quantity. We came hungry and left happy.
author: Parker R.

description:
I had not heard much about this place, but I loved everything we ordered! The staff was incredibly nice, and though some of the customers were entitled, the staff was so courteous. Would definitely recommend the tacos and pretty much everything else we tried on the menu. 

Super impressed!!
author: Hannah W.

description:
I went there last night to get take out. While I was waiting for the food, I sat at the bar and ordered a beer. Halfway through my beer, the bartender tells me I can't sit at the bar because I ordered take out, and he wants to sit two patrons who just arrived. I complied but told him there was no reason for this, since I had order a beer while sitting at the bar; what if I just wanted to go there for drinks? He offered a reply that was  both condescending and patronizing. If a customer politely tells you they feel wronged by your attitude, the first thing you do is apologize, not tell them they're wrong.

When I told the hostess about it, she just awkwardly stared back at me and said that there was nothing she could do. Before I left with the food I asked the hostess if there was a manager I could speak to. She said that there was a manager, but he was very busy. If a patron asks to speak to the manager, and there's one on staff at the moment, the only acceptable reply is "yes, right away".

In terms of food, the Spicy Noodles with Char Siu pork are quite good. The Papaya Salad was dry and had too much cabbage in it. The food, bad attitude, and beer were $37 in total, which feels overpriced even for that area.
author: Jan S.

description:
Loud and small restaurant for Millennials that love to eat Asian fusion with the music blaring. Don't bring mom! The food is fantastic any night of the week, but the music and crowds get turnt up on the weekend for dinner and brunch. 

The food is served small plate style, which is no ones favorite, but there are lots of hearty options, so you can get away with just ordering a few. Order the Korean Tacos, Kobe Beef Noodles, and poke or Curry Lemongrass Vermicelli. 

The Spicy Garlic Noodles are over rated. There's not much meat and the noodles are so greesy that you feel sick even if you split it in half. Order the Kobe Beef Chow Mein instead. You still get the noodles, but it comes with some extra protein and greens.

They allow reservations for large groups, but otherwise expect to wait for a table on the weekends. Come on Sunday for their bottomless drinks and iconic mini duckies. I suggest their Cold Tea because it's a less sweet sake-based alternative to their standard mimosas and sangria. 

I'm very impressed they serve craft beer from Fort Point Brewing!
author: Kendra C.

description: Great atmosphere but the food here is very mediocre. Greasy and the taste of it is not great but still manageable to swallow.
author: Monica L.

description:
5 star for ambience. Played good music--Hip Hop/Rap/R&B vibe. It was bumpin the whole time. Felt like a nightclub except it was 10am. 

It was my first time there and also my bday weekend so I decided to go big. We did the $37 all you can eat mix & match brunch. The brunch includes bottomless drinks. Mind you I don't drink, no less drink at 10am. But it's my bday...turning the BIG Three Five so gotta live a little. 

You get 90min to eat all you want, drink all you want...and I was done 45 min in. Who eats and drinks that much? Still, loved the environment. It was hip and cool and the food was good. I had the breakfast jook, dumplings, pork bun, chow mein, salt & pepper shrimp, and kale salad. All pretty good. My fav was the dumplings. 

For drinks I had the sangria and iced green tea ( which has sake in it) and a shot of Sake. The Sake was super smooth. Have no idea what kind it was but it was the best I've had---but I haven't had much. Again, I don't drink. I just like the fact that it didn't burn going down the hatch and I didn't have to make faces that would embarrass myself. 

All in all---if you got a few in the group and don't mind burning some time I say go for it! I would have stayed longer just to listen to music and vibe on the energy but it got too crowded.
author: Bunny P.

description: Always perfect. From food to the service. The waiters know my orders by now and tailor the food choices without me even asking. Perfect customer service. Will be back again and again. Thanks guys!
author: Vika N.

description:
Such a fun vibe and killer playlist - you'll be jamming out and ready to go out before, during and most definitely after dinner! Showed up on a Saturday without reservation and was promptly seated, though the place filled up FAST. 

Ordered the garlic noodles with pork and tuna sashimi. They serve the sashimi with shrimp crackers (the light air-y kind), which was a first and I didn't find they complemented each other very well. No biggie, just ate them separately. Both dishes were delicious, if slightly on the salty end. A good match with the restaurant atmosphere - loud, energetic and flavorful haha. 

Good place to take a friend / visitor who likes hip without pretension and mid to upscale fusion without mood lighting :) 

Can't wait to come back to try the dim sum!!
author: Jennifer L.

description: My favorite restaurant during my entire week long visit to San Francisco. Order the pork tacos. They were delicious. The restaurant was packed and the vibe was so cool. They played great music and our server, I'm almost positive her name was Katrina or Katia, was so nice and informative. She recommended her favorites and told us what was popular. She even brought sake shots to our table for my birthday. Definitely a place I would visit again!
author: Jackie M.

description:
I had high hopes for this place as it was recommended by many of my friends for brunch. To be fair, $39 for bottomless mimosas and all you can eat dim sum is really not bad. If you are coming for the experience and want to get drunk and have a good time with the food as a side, then I'd say this place is for you. However, if you're like me and place a high emphasis on the food, you may be disappointed.

Starting with the drinks; they had a few options, I tried the sangria and mimosa, both were pretty good. I thought it was really cute how they added a tiny rubber ducky to each of the drinks! Each table has two servers, a drink server and a food server. Our drink server was very on top of keeping our glasses filled.

Now onto the food: mediocre at best. We tried every single item on the AYCE brunch menu, and the only dish I was really impressed with was the Szechuan string beans and pork buns. The rest of the dishes were honestly like a level or two above Panda Express. Also, it just really bothered me that they tried to pass off roasted duck with buns as Peking duck and didn't bother to remove the bones before serving the meat to us. 

Also, the music was WAY too loud. They blast tunes here like it's a club or something. You know it's a problem when your server has to ask repeatedly what you are saying. My friends and I basically yelled at each other throughout the entire meal and just decided to kind of give up talking altogether because it was just so much effort. I honestly think it kind of ruined my dining experience, and when I asked the server if they could turn it down a little, they said the best they could do was lower it by a notch. I thought that perhaps it was because my group was seated kind of close to the speaker, but while in line for the bathroom, I spoke to other parties who also agreed that it was way too loud to be enjoyable. We came expecting to eat at a restaurant not a club.
author: Brenda L.

description: BRUNCH! I haven't been there for anything else, but brunch is truly an experience. You must make a reservation and you will be stuffed and tipsy walking out. They bring dishes out for about an hour, you don't order off a menu, but you can tell them what on the menu you don't want. Once they have brought all the dishes once they will come back around to see if you have any items you want round 2 of. Only reason I gave it 4 instead of 5 stars is due to the fact that once the 2 hours is up, you can't just sit and hang with your friends you are out. They need to set up for the next seating.
author: Catherine G.

description: We loved loved loved the Chubby Noodle! We had the Korean Tacos, Calamari and Noodles with Fried Chicken. All the dishes were prepared beautifully, perfect spices and heat. We will definitely be coming back. Our waiter was lovely and very informative. Our first visit was the day before Valentine's Day and the perfect place to eat before our concert that evening.
author: Dina L.

description:
The food here is amazing. We got the wings, ribs, curry lemongrass vermicelli and the tacos. Literally 10/10

The tacos are to die for.
author: Ajay G.

description:
I was hella feeling the music at Chubby Noodle. Yes, it might be a little loud at first... but once you sit in there for about 5 minutes you get used to it. You'll be body rollin' while eating your meal and you won't even know it! Lol.

+ Chubby garlic noodes + fried chicken - the fried chicken was just ok... but I really loved the noodles. I was already full and just kept eating them. SO bomb.

+ Duck lettuce wraps - the duck comes out on a sizzling place and it is very flavorful. Served with butter lettuce, cucumber, and a yummy fish sauce. I liked it.

Lots of local craft beers -- I ordered one of their IPAs (can't remember the name, sorry!!) and it was really good.

Good food and hella good vibes. Affordable and would def be back.
author: Elysse P.

description:
I really enjoyed my impromptu meal here one evening as I happened to be in the neighborhood.  I sat at the bar, and I asked the bartender what the popular dishes are.  It was just me, but I wanted to try a variety of dishes and planned to pack up what I couldn't eat.  

I started out with a pork taco (they serve these yummy tacos until they run out) - it was sooo flavorful and filling.  I could have eaten maybe 3 for a solo meal, but I wanted to try other dishes while I was there.  The bartender gave me a Chubby Sake to go with my meal - thank you, yum!  It complimented the food perfectly.

I got the spicy garlic noodles and I had to add the fried chicken to it!  This dish made me sweat but it was so worth it, and the fried chicken is a must-add.  Ask your waiter for "firecracker sauce" as the bartender recommended to me on the side to add as you like - this was another layer of kicking flavor!  It's a nice, healthy serving so I definitely had to take 2/3s of it home (so good as leftovers though!).  I also had an order of the Chinese green beans which was a nice healthy, vegetable add to my meal - I took a good portion of it home too.  

The bartender gave me another Chubby Sake - thank you!  He was so nice and attentive.  

Thank you!  I will definitely be back!
author: Maile N.

description:
From LA to SF Hell yaaa come visit this place, 
Customer service on point very friendly and also clean 
Hands on the best place at SF
author: La R.

description:
The good:
1. The food here is to die for. The duck, the dumplings, the pork buns, and fried rice were are terrifically seasoned and hearty (and I don't even like Asian food that much).

2. The ambience is a great scene to be with fund friends at a group brunch or etc.

3. The service is amazing!!! Most attentive staff ever 

The bad:
1. The seats and tables are for midgets 

2. A bit pricey (even for San Fran)

3. The share plates are too small 

So notes:

HAVE A RESERVATION

Great for friend reunions. Not great for first dates (3rd dates maybe).
author: Hall W.

description:
Fun spot to eat, but make sure you are ready for some fun.  Lots of music, drinks and people!

And if you come at prime time be ready for a line
author: Chris M.

description:
Garlic noodles. Green beans. Pork buns. Salt and pepper shrimp. I don't think a single dish here disappoints. I take every single friend visiting here- it's a must. If you're feeling extra adventurous try out their brunch - $39 for bottomless food, mimosas/sangria... yasss please. 

PS. Marina location trumps North Beach (too bad it's not on Postmates) #rip
author: Lauren S.

description: Wow, just wow. I'm going to start off by saying how cool and energetic the vibe is. They play awesome music and the staff is so friendly. Now onto the food..I ordered papaya salad, garlic noodles with added fried chicken, ribs, and korean tacos. Oh my goodness it was all so tasty, I can't even explain. You must try!!! Reasonable prices as well :)
author: Audrey H.

description:
Every bite of every dish was delicious. I especially loved the fried chicken that we added to our noodles, but everything from the BBQ pork fried rice to the drinks was amazing. 

Music was a little loud and raunchy, considering we were there early with our young daughter, but that's not the crowd that they cater to, so I don't blame them. Go to here.
author: Ian B.

description: Brunch here is amazing!!!!!!! The salt and pepper shrimp is to die for and the jook is good too. $37 for unlimited drink and food.
author: Tina L.

description: I love this place. They have their system down. Somehow service is amazing, even though it's super busy and small 24/7. We told the waiter to just bring us whatever he wanted, and it was all delicious. Bonus: if you're vegetarian or someone in your group is, you can tell them and they'll bring plenty of veggie dishes. At one point we literally had to tell the waiter to stop bringing food. That's how much they give you. Music is amazing and the vibe is super fun. Only downside is sometimes it can be slow to get a refill, so you end up with a ton of food and nothing to wash it down for a bit.
author: Sara T.

description: I love this place. We got here right when the restaurant opened for friday dinner and they seated the two of us right away. We ordered salt & pepper shrimp, spicy garlic noodles, and washed it down with Asahi. The dipping sauce for the shrimp was AMAZING, and the noodles were just the right amount of spicy, and if you want to make it hotter it tastes great with sriracha. Service was fast and friendly, and I love the hip hop atmosphere. Will definitely go here again and try out the brunch!
author: Noelle N.

description:
Yay for having my favorite beer, Hitachino. I was able to snag a spot at their intimate bar to enjoy one while waiting for a table. Wait wasn't too bad on a Saturday evening. 

It's a loud, bustling restaurant. Be prepared to talk just as loudly. The kitchen is small and open and the woks are hot and constantly in use which means (ladies especially) be prepared for your hair and clothes to smell like fried food from a Chinese restaurant once you leave if you're by the kitchen.  

Skip the Korean bbq tacos.
Maybe skip the fried rice. 
Salmon sashimi was good but felt out of place on our table.
Garlic noodles and chicken was delicious! Winner.
Papaya salad was refreshing and necessary amongst the heavy food.

If you like spicy you'll like Chubby Noodle. It's expensive for what it is but if you want a variety of Asian inspired foods and not go to a traditional Asian restaurant, this is a great place.
author: Samantha L.

description:
I came here for the first time with a reservation for the weekend bottomless brunch.

First impression: Absolute skepticism. Despite being an Asian restaurant, my friends and I were the only Asians in the entire restaurant, so we were all skeptical about how good the food would be. Plus the music was BLASTING hip-hop, which we didn't mind, but it's a completely different feel from the ambience of the typical SF brunch spot.

Happy to say that we were pleasantly surprised with everything!

Our waiter (wish I remembered his name) was super friendly and helpful. He made sure to order a bunch of items for us and kept the food and the drinks flowing nonstop at a great pace. He even offered a round of free sake shots because we had to wait about 10-15 minutes past our original reservation time. Definitely appreciated that gesture!

We tried pretty much everything on the menu, but there were some highlights:
- Mimosas: A bit different than traditional because it was like a glass of fruity champagne instead of champagne with orange juice, but it tasted great.
- Breakfast jook: Very unique, super flavorful. Loved the addition of the bacon and egg! My boyfriend doesn't usually like jook, but he loved this too.
- Garlic green beans: Surprisingly good. Really well cooked, and we all loved the sauce.
- Peking duck steam buns: A must-order to get the most bang for your buck. The skin was crispy too!
- Salt and pepper shrimp: They were fried similar to calamari, and it came with a super addicting creamy sauce.

Overall, it was definitely a pricey brunch at $50/person after tax and tip, but we definitely got our money's worth and were happy with the service and the food, as well as the number of drinks we all ordered.
author: Sara L.

description: The place is loud and the waiters make you feel like you have to rush. I asked for ice and didn't get it till the end of my meal. The vegan options here are nothing special and even my non-vegan friends didn't enjoy their meal. Overpriced .
author: Lense E.

description: Was looking forward to trying this place, but you need a reservation for brunch. The guy in the front was really rude... "next time you should get a reservation because you can't eat here without one". Yeah or I could just not come back with your bad attitude. He could tell me and my friend were taken aback by his tone and passed us off to this one of his other coworkers, but still... DONT BE A DOUCHEBAG.
author: Stephanie F.

description: Great service, decent food. This place is definitely Americanized dim sum (I think my group was the only Asians in the place), but that was the sort of food I was expecting. Everything was pretty good (aside from the breakfast porridge, which was way too salty for me). We really came here for the AYCD option. There was an assortment of 4 drink choices, which were pretty tasty, and the servers were great with the refills. I'm happy that I tried this place out once for the experience, but I probably wouldn't come back.
author: Cynthia M.

description: YUMMMM! Such a good place for dinner, the fried chicken is unreal. I loved the Poke bowl, and the BBQ Korean tacos-so many good flavors. The garlic noodles were nothing special in my mind, but I couldn't get enough of the chicken, poke and tacos!
author: Raychel J.

description:
Did we just luck out on timing or something, because the experience I had was near perfect here.

After hiking all day on Mt. Tam, on our way back into the city due to construction changes, we wanted to grab dinner in the Marina. Saw the good reviews for Chubby Noodle and got a thumbs up from another member of our party. 

We got there around 6 on Sunday and it had a crowd but there was no wait. Got seated right by the door, and our server/manager was fantastic. Friendly, polite, willing to explain the family-style ordering, and willing to answer any questions. I had some about the on tap sake and the Yona Yona Beer, and while he didn't know he asked the bartender and provided the answer. 

We ended up getting a few items for the table. We were hungry, but not ravenous from the hike, so we got in order of delivery:

Pork and Shrimp Wontons: probably the weakest of the items, but not bad by any means. The  spicy soy sauce seeps in and gives it a wonderful kick that we all noticed. 8 pieces per bowl gave us each two, so enough to enjoy.

Papaya Salad: this was really good, really light, and really refreshing. Yummy papaya, bean sprouts, mint, basil in a light vinegar dressing. Everyone got a huge amount.

Kimchee: this was definitely my suggestion, and I did end up killing it as it was great. Some of the Korean spots in San Jose make a pretty tame kimchee. This had a great little kick that wasn't overpowering. 

Spicy Garlic Noodles: not as spicy as I expected, but perfectly tender and did have some good flavor. Unfortunately I didn't know you could get char siu pork added to it, but it was great on it's own for the carb.

Tuna Poke: a nice-sized portion of cubed tuna that comes with those Chinese Shrimp Chips, so you can make your own little tuna poke nachos. Fantastic flavor on these, I think we were all being polite just not stealing the whole plate.

Duck Tacos: generally when you see something like "available until sold out" you know it is going to be good. It exceeded expectations. By far the best item we tried, and we all mumbling suggested getting another order despite being full. Only one tortilla, so not purely authentic, but the duck is delicious and the bit of yogurt really does add to the flavor.

After the meal but before the bill, I talked with our server/manager and one of the bartenders - as the garlic noodles were delicious, I asked if they ever did dandan noodles. Neither had heard of the dish, but they did start to scramble to find their own dinner for the night. But they did tell me about SO and PPQ doing so.

I loved everything here, but I realize that timing was a big factor (the neighborhood was practically empty) and that not all patrons would experience this. But I definitely recommend it.
author: Michael C.

description:
I've been wanting to try Chubby Noodle for ages, but I was definitely surprised to see the low health score warning. I'm not really the type to get too turned off but something like this (especially for a restaurant that's pretty highly rated), so I decided to give it a shot anyways.

A friend and I went to their endless dim sum brunch on a Sunday pretty close to opening, and there were already quite a few people seated. Be warned that the space is very small and I don't think they take brunch reservations, so coming early is definitely recommended. Also, beware that even with the size they still allow larger groups inside, which in our case was a bit annoying because there was a group of at least 10 that didn't have enough seats, so a lot of them were standing in the way of everything.

The endless brunch includes unlimited pick of 15 or so items, along with 4 glasses of one of their brunch cocktails. Although there's a drink max, they're actually pretty strong after you have a couple, so it wasn't as disappointing that there wasn't a bottomless option. We also had a great waitress who kept bringing us sake shots so that didn't hurt either!

It's definitely hard to not go over board when ordering since it's unlimited, and I definitely went a little crazy. I started off with the breakfast jook, a breakfast porridge with egg and bacon that was delicious and soothing. I also ordered the pork and shrimp dumpling, duck steam buns (which are huge and filling and I definitely recommend sharing!), kung pao wings (not my favorite from the menu), chow mein, and green beans. 

Everything overall was amazing, I just wish I had paced myself a little more, because believe me you'll get full fast. I will say with the size and the amount of people that were there that day, and the fact that there was only one waitress, the service was kind of slow. And I did notice that tables that were seated after us got some of the same dishes we ordered before we did, but again our waitress was really nice so it didn't really effect our overall experience.

I highly recommend coming here if you're looking for a fresh take on a dim sum brunch. If you're worried about the health warning, just know I didn't get sick after eating here and I didn't see anything weird in the food, so don't let it stop you from trying it out!
author: Jaymie S.

description:
Get ready for a lively and fun atmosphere to be in on any day of the week! This place is great food, great drinks and really good service.

The service is super sociable, quick service, and great at making recommendations if its your first time here.

In terms of food I would recommend the spicy garlic noodles (such great flavor and you will be blowing garlic for days after), the korean pork tacos made with chili yogurt (limited quantities until they sell out), and the salmon sashimi with the creamy avocado paste.
author: Kunal T.

description:
Was in San Francisco for a business trip.  I was done late, and hungry.  Chubby Noodle was down the street from my hotel.  It was close to closing time and I asked the server what he recommended. He said the Chubby Noodle is known for their pork tacos and their BBQ beef rice.  So I ordered it and when my tacos arrived,  my first thought was "I am going to order more, because this is not enough"  there were two of us and not sure if we would have enough good for both of us.
Not only were the tacos delicious,  they are loaded with pork. One taco was more than enough for me.  We also had the BBQ beef fried rice and that too was delicious and it was a generous serving.
We were very hungry as we traveled all day and worked for a few hours as soon as we got it the city. 
The music was bumpin' - rap. The chunky noodle had a bar like, fun  vibe. Only in San Francisco can you eat noodles to rap music. I'm going back when I'm in SF
author: Sylhouettes by Sylvia M.

description:
Bro gave me my drink & said, "Remember to shake it."
Oh I shook it alright...
Shook it to Chingy, Ashanti, Tupac, Beastie Boys,
And whoever else blasted during my #thirdmeal.
#wait was he talking about the Yoo-Hoo bottle?
Because I was shaking eeeeeverything.

Menu & hours bigger than their other spots; handy.
#demribsdoe #datyoohoodoe #lawaroundhereyougottowearyoursunglassessoyoucanfeelcoolgangsterlean
author: Dan B.

description: I absolutely love places like this. My friends and I all decided to gather here for a good meal after some fun. We all must have been on the same page because we all ordered the same dish which was the Spicy Garlic Noodles. They were actually really really good! No complaints about the taste of the noodles whatsoever!! UNTIL..... we look over and are all accompanied by baby roaches!!!! Are you kidding me?!! This is NOT OKAY!! We first noticed them on the window at another table and they made their way towards us. We notified the staff immediately!! They kindly took care of our bill but I will NEVER eat there again!! Of course, unless you'd like to eat roaches for lunch.
author: Amy A.

description:
The Service:
First I have to say the wait staff and manager are amazing folks.  They really stood out on service for me.  I had walked from AT&T park to go to the location in the Italian village just to find out it was closed for a private event.  The staff there went above and beyond to take care of me and get me to this location and phoned ahead to the manager to let them know my plight.

I didn't need it, but the manager there gave me personal service and he and his staff went above and beyond for me.  It was greatly appreciated by me and I want everyone to know that these guys give great service on top of already great and tasty food.

The Food:
I had the garlic noodles with prawns... holy geez that was super tasty, you got the garlic and the nice texture from the egg noodles mixed with the slightly sweet meat from the shrimp, finished off with just the right amount of heat from the jalapeños (not too hot but very tasty)

I also had the Korean Pork Tacos.  I was getting full by this point but I managed to make more room for these tasty delectables.  The pork has a nice char / crispy outside yet was juicy and melted in my mouth.  The nice creamy sauce and sweet cucumbers added depth to the already maxing pork, not to be overshadowed by the crisp yet maliable home made tortilla which brought the flavors all together.

All of this was washed down with their smooth, ice cold house sake.

This was a fantastic meal by a fantastic staff in a fantastic location.  I will definitely be coming back for seconds
author: Shawn R.

description:
Hipster is always a mixture of cool and overpriced. Sometimes they lean more on cool so the priceiness is worth it. Sometimes they are mediocrely cool and way overpriced and you feel like you're paying solely for Instagram popularity. Chubby Noodle was unfortunately the latter -_- 

Despite the name, there is nothing chubby about their noodles; on the contrary, the portions are TINY! We paid ~$15 per person and ate burgers at Super Duper afterwards. 

The server recommended Korean pork tacos and spicy garlic noodles. The tacos are essentially the only thing unique enough to be worth getting, in my opinion, but taking into account the $$$ I'm not sure I would recommend. Everything else is overpriced mediocre Asian food plated in hipster fashion (e.g. + runny fried egg).

TUNA POKE ($13) sesame, soy, sambal, macadamia | Not bad and I liked the kick of spice sauteed into the edamame However the fish was a little too mushy, and the portion size was wayyyy tiny... so tiny I felt like it impaired my ability to accurately assess it.

KOREAN PORK TACO ($11 for 2) house made flour tortilla, chili yogurt, cucumber | Fusion masterpiece! The tortilla is very similar to that delicious savory wrap they use for TW beef/green onion pancake. The Korean BBQ pork was on point with the fatteningly delicious chili sesame oil marinade, and the addition of the cucumber and yogurt made it a bit reminiscent of time-tested Greek kebab wraps. Perfect in every respect until you realize it's a $5 taco -_-

BBQ PORK FRIED RICE ($10+$2) Chinese pork, egg, scallions / add fried egg | We expected a creative spin but it was really just your typical BBQ fried rice that you could get for half the price at any decent Chinese restaurant. (Plus runny fried egg for the Instagram)

CHICKEN CHOW MEIN ($11) house made noodles, vegetables | Nothing special. It's regular chow mein with a topping of chubby rice noodles for the Chubby Noodle namesake, but I feel like it doesn't actually go well with the chow mein. Fried rice noodles are not used this way in Chinese cooking... noodles as a topping for noodles hardly makes sense, aiyah!

KUNG PAO WINGS ($10) arbol chilies, garlic, ginger | A little zingier than your average kung pao, but nothing mind-blowing (especially if you've had the famous San Tung wings)

SPICY GARLIC NOODLES ($10) house made egg noodles, garlic, jalapeno | Definitely not the best garlic noodles I've had, but likely the smallest portion I've had -_-

The verdict: I would give Chubby Noodle a try if you are super into Asian fusion, have excessive dispensable income, or go die-hard on finding the best possible Instagrams. A la carte is expensive, so I would suggest trying the weekend bottomless brunch--ACYE might actually make you chubby :3
author: Edna C.

description: Ate here our first night in the city, and have to say the food was amazing!  Small and cozy atmosphere, very friendly staff, and our waitress (Gabrialla) was awesome, she recommended great choices and was very nice.  Would highly recommend anything with the fried chicken.
author: Brian R.

description: I was seated at a high top table with my party and I noticed a person working took a piece of chicken from a fried chicken dish that was then served. So gross. Never coming back here!
author: Ravina Y.

description: THIS PLACE IS NEXT LEVEL. Definitely one of my favorite spots in the city with a fun atmosphere, hip hop from the 90's, fantastic staff and food. This joint used to be a Thai restaurant and the new style this place brings is definitely worth checking out. Try the pad thai and the tacos!
author: Michael B.

description: Had this place for delivery one night. The food was good, but not AMAZING. I had their noodles. I would like to try it for brunch.
author: Makenzi B.

description: Spicy garlic noodles are pretty good! When I was here the special that day was a duck wrap, which was also yummy and savory in fresh butter lettuce wrap.
author: Jeana Y.

description: Went here after work and had a small plate and sake flight. Must say didn't expect much but the place had good music and the sake was pretty good. I'd go back again
author: R M.

description:
Solid place for a Saturday dinner. I called earlier in the day to make a reservation for six people. They let me know that the charge for no-show-no-call would be $25/person, so I made sure everyone in my party would show. They also called me roughly two hours beforehand to confirm. If you have a bigger group, I highly recommend making a reservation. But, be careful, because they are quite strict about their policies...

This is another one of those places that won't seat you until you entire party is seated. I get that, but it just stinks that we can't sit first (read: spend more money on drinks and appetizers) while we wait for the rest of our party. Only when we literally told them that the last person was looking for parking (again, we went on Saturday night) and had the text messages to prove it, did they agree to seat the five of us. That just kind of bugs me in general about the more chill places like this one. For a very high-end, dress-code place, I understand. But it seemed to be a little overkill here because they were such sticklers about it.

We ordered the Chubby Noodle sake, which we were told was the "signature." It was nice and mild, so it paired well with the flavorful food. Food-wise, we got the Lettuce Wraps, Korean Pork Tacos, Garlic Noodles with BBQ Pork, and Chow Mein. Personally, I thought the Lettuce Wraps were just okay. I liked that they gave you the carrots, cucumber, and radish on the side, but I thought this was a little too greasy. Same thing with the Korean Pork Tacos, but those were better in terms of flavor. The Garlic Noodles were delicious~ but a little too spicy for my taste. Still, I liked that dish the best. The Chow Mein was also good, especially the texture. So they're definitely noodle masters here!

Service, aside from the seating part of the night, was great. They constantly came by to ask us if we needed anything and refilled our drinks.

My friend noticed that by the time we finished our meal, the table next to us, who had been waiting even before we got there, was just then getting seated. Making a reservation was clutch!

Couple of minor details: music playlist was bomb, but a little too loud. Also, it can get stuffy if you're seated close to the kitchen. Lastly, they have a limit on the number of cards they take, so take that into account if you have a bigger group and want to split.
author: Eryn H.

description:
All you can eat dim sum and drinks.
Food: More like an Americanized dim sum. Don't expect traditional dim sum dishes like chicken feet or shrimp rolls here. They have fried rice, noodles, Peking duck, fried shrimp, wontons, etc. Overal the food wasn't great dim sum and was a little on the salty side, but still tasty enough to try a little bit of everything. 
Drinks: 4 different drinks are included in the price and sake is a la cart. The drinks were a little watered down, but the service was fast at refilling cups so you can get your money's worth. They also add a small duck to each cup for extra flair.

Be sure to make a reservation! The restaurant was pretty much full the entire 90 minutes we were there and the tables are pretty small. I'd recommend coming with a group or 4 or less for the regular table.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Alright, if there was a 3.5 stars I would definitely hand it to them. Took me so long to write a review after coming here back in November 2015 because I couldn't quite collect myself to compose a review with such mixed feelings. Food portions were small, quality was definitely not authentic (but hey, its Asian FUSION, understood), BUT THE STAFF WERE SOOOO AMAZING. 

::Service/Atmosphere/Parking::
Came here for a reunion with two of my buddies Ben T. and Kevin S.
From beginning to end, service was just top notch: attentive, friendly, and everything in between. Our waitress noticed that both of my friends were doing the sakes and I (who has retired from the SHOT O'CLOCK days) didnt have alcohol in my hand, hooked me up with a shot so I wouldnt be empty handed. TY! 
There was a bit of a wait on one of our dish, it was towards the end of our meal already and we still didnt get it and just as we were gonna cancel it, it came out. She apologized for the delay and everything. 
Atmosphere was pretty loud, not for romantic dinner dates haha. The place felt a bit hipstery and had interesting decors all around. The restaurant was smaller than usual but my party of 3 got seated immediately on a Friday night. 
Parking I didnt even sweat because I was with the locals who knew SF parking inside out. And plus, we got VIP parking right in front of the restaurant. 

::FOOD:: 
SPICY GARLIC NOODLES 10: egg noodle, charred garlic, jalapeno. mmm it was in a small bowl and a very small portion. It was just OK to be flavor wise. IT WASNT TOO SPICY, BOOYA (i cant handle spicy)! A bit plain to my taste buds. 
KOREAN PORK TACOS 11: came with yogurt chili sauce, cucumber. This was the one that took us the entire meal to get. It only comes with 2 tacos I believe, the waitress was nice enough to throw in a 3rd one for us. SEE WHAT I MEAN??? This was probably my favorite one as the pork was packed with a lot of flavors. 
BBQ PORK FRIED RICE 8: 'char sui' chinese style BBQ pork, egg, scallions. Something simple. nothing too special or extraordinary from the other fried rice I've had the past 23 years of my life. 

I was SO eager to try the Peking Duck Steam Bun, but they were out for the day by the time we got there :'( NEXT TIME. 

Overall a very Americanized Asian Fusion. A bit pricey... but their staff are SOOOOOOOO friendly and amazing!
author: Chena N.

description: This small little hole in the wall is definitely a place to try. The food was good and the service was great. We ordered the fried chicken, garlic noodles with shrimp, pork tacos and green beans. This was more than enough for two with left overs to be taken home. The green beans were my favorite. The garlic noodles were pretty Spicy and had a different taste to them that I can't quite figure out. The tacos were definitely tasty. And the shell was a different texture than a tortilla. Not quite sure if it was an actual tortilla or not. But it was pretty good. The fried chicken was boneless and the dipping sauce set off the chicken.  Everything was not served all at once but when it was received it was all hot and fresh off the grill. The waitress was friendly. The decor was perfect for the type of restaurant. Something different that was not expected was the music they played. It was hard core rap. And was unfiltered of all profanity. Definitely different and not what you would expect.
