More for a younger crowd enjoying the night life for sure. We ordered drinks and they had a weird name, something like titty for the kitty, and I could not finish mine. It was not something I would ordered again. Over all the place was nice, food was good and service was good. I did have to ask for forks so we could eat our food because they only had chop sticks in a container on the table.
author: Ashley L.

description: Loved the late 90s early 2000s hip hop playlist! Delicious food. Service was quick. Got real busy on a Friday evening. Two items we ordered were already out even though they were only open for about half an hour.
author: Sydney Y.

description:
You can't come here and not get the garlic noodles. The calamari with the jalapeño sauce is also amazing. 

It's a super casual place, and the staff is really friendly. It gets pretty busy on any given day,  but definitely worth that wait! Would recommended to anyone!
author: Rafat N.

description:
The food here is good but nothing special. However, this place is amazing.

Here's why: They take reservations for large groups, and they have an all you can eat and all you can drink (i.e., bottomless) dim sum brunch for about ~50pp including tax and tip. Go here with all your friends, and drink and eat as much as you can. If your group is big enough you can pretty much get everything to try (and then some). I liked the dumplings and pork buns, but anything tastes good after you're a few drinks in :)
author: Tanay J.

description:
I was two Long Island ice teas deep when I ate here but I definitely remember a few things very clearly.
1. I unintentionally ate a pepper from one of the plates and my mouth was on fire. I think I went into shock because I wasn't expecting it and there couldn't have been enough water to tame the pain
2. The place was really hip and really crowded. We came at 7 and put our names down and waited an hour. Fortunately they texted us so we could walk down a block to a bar beforehand which is how I got 2 Long Island ice teas in.
3. pretty hard to forget that pepper
author: Julianna I.

description: It just ok.. didn't blow my hair back like a San Francisco place should.  Prices didn't seem right for what we ate.  Food wasn't bad, just bland and boring.  I don't think for the money I would eat here again.  This 7 square miles of San Francisco is full of 100,000 plus places to try.
author: Matthew U.

description: Walking around town looking for a place to eat came across the chubby noodle.. first thing I noticed was the atmosphere.. they were playing great music .. the wait for a table was 45 min so I grabbed a table at the bar. The food was amazing try the pork tacos or fried rice you won't be disappointed
author: William S.

description:
Yay for Chubby Noodles! Being on Miami standards, we tend to miss dinner when we travel by showing up at 10p but we were sat immediately. Fortunately this spot was alive and cookin! 

Super cool kid on the block vibe. Good music. Dark and cozy. Fried rice with pork was delish.. but the Chubby Chicken Chow Mein.. didn't stand a chance! And I perfected my chop stick skills. You gotta love those little victories.
author: Elizabeth G.

description: Recommended by several friends that used to live in Bay Area. Wasn't too keen on the menu online but after a third recommendation we decided to try it out-- and we were not disappointed. The service was quick, personable and friendly, considering it was a Friday night after 7pm. We sat at the bar, Marco was FABULOUS at recommendations on food, sake and general knowledge of the menu. We ordered the spicy garlic noodles with fried chicken and the BBQ pork fried rice with a fried egg. The spicy garlic noodles was phenomenal and I would recommend it over and over. The BBQ pork fried rice was good, but would have been better with the fried chicken in it and some spice, rather than BBQ pork. Overall great experience, would totally recommend to try if you're in the Cow Hollow/Marina area!
author: Courtney B.

description: I wasn't a fan of this place. We came around 4pm thinking it would be pretty slow but ended up getting the last table but squeezed in the back corner. The music was so loud you couldn't carry on any conversation if you wanted to and it wasn't my taste in music either...a lot of cursing etc. We had our little girl with us so I wasn't enthused to hear that while we were trying to eat. My husband ordered the spicy garlic noodles and i ordered the fried rice because I knew my daughter would at least eat that. His food came first and it wasn't spicy at all (luckily) because we had to wait another 15-20 minutes on the fried rice so my daughter was able to eat some of his noodles. This place is NOT for children and the menu is pretty small. The rice was ok but I have had better.
author: Lauren M.

description:
Yummy!  A little over priced, but overall still a tasty meal.  On a Sunday night, our group was estimated a 45 minute wait, but luckily we got seated in half that time.  SCORE!  

The food is "tapas style", but this is Asian so I would probably say it's more like "dim sum style".  I was sad they ran out of the duck.

*Pork tacos- good crispy tortillas, delicious pork.  Whatever the tortillas are made of, they were on point 
Pork dumplings
Papaya salad- refreshing, I really liked the mint
Shrimp- pretty good
*Chicken wings- spicy for my sensitive palate but it hurt so gooooood
Garlic noodles with chicken- so so

All the food was tasty, but the (*) are must gets.  The only thing that I could pass on were the noodles, which was ironic to me cause of the name of this place.

It was just enough food for 4-5 people without being overly stuffed.  They play good music, service was very friendly and quick.  Bonus points for hooks under the tables for bags.
author: Lyn C.

description:
Great Food + Bottomless Drinks = Dancing like fools at Eastside West with the biggest smiles.

I would definitely recommend going as a group of 4 or more as their portions are large and this way you get to try most of their menu. They are extremely prompt in bringing out their dishes and drinks. We enjoyed all the dishes that came out and definitely enjoyed our entire day thereafter ;)
author: Tarun P.

description: My wife and I were looking for a late dinner in the area. We had picked another place and were walking there when we saw/smelled this place. They were only going to be open for another 30 minutes but they welcomed us in. We ordered the garlic noodles and Korean tacos. As we were waiting our waiter asked us if we liked chicken, pork or shrimp. I told him pork. Along with our order he also brought pork ribs on the house. Everything was excellent but the ribs were mine and my wife's favorite dish. We had excellent service and the food was great. We came back the next night for the ribs and we got the same great service. Best pork I've ever had. Can't wait to visit SF again, we'll definitely be back here.
author: Eric R.

description:
I did the all you can eat brunch with three other people on a Saturday at noon. We ordered everything on the menu and I really enjoyed my experience at this restaurant! There was no wait, service was friendly and attentive, the ambience was great, drinks were unlimited, and the food was tasty. It was expensive at over $40 per person with tax and tip but I had fun and felt I got my money's worth. 

FAVORITES: 
- Mimosa - I tried the sangria and the tea as well but this was the only drink I enjoyed because I prefer sweet drinks. Sapporo was also an option if you like beer. The mimosas and sangria come with tiny rubber ducks which I loved! The tea came in a cute mug but I wasn't a huge fan of the tea itself. 
- Shrimp dumplings - Out of all the different types of dumplings we tried, this was my favorite. 
- Peking duck - Fatty and delicious
- Porridge (Jook) - Great comfort food
- Salt and Pepper Shrimp - Salty, flavorful and came with a mayo-like dipping sauce.
- Wings - Sweet and salty
- Wonton Soup - This was my favorite in the last round of dishes that came out of the kitchen. It was hot and comforting. 

I would recommend sharing your meal with at least three people so you can try everything!
author: Karen L.

description:
Me and my friends are not from SF, we were walking around to find a place to eat, then we stopped here! My first impression was: how come a restaurant so much likely like a bar?! Lol anw, yes it is all you and eat and drink! That makes sense!!! However, we only eat, so the price reduces to $28/person. I believe we came at happy hour, i'm not sure. 
It was a great experience!
author: Tiffany T.

description:
This is my go-to for so many different occasions - brunch, lunch, late lunch, dinner! Always a good time and good food. 

Chubby Noodle serves smaller plates that are perfect to share and encourages you to try multiple items! 

What should you order?
- Poke Tuna
- Pork Wontons
- Spicy Garlic Noodles (but beware of the copious amounts of garlic!)
- Chubby Fried Rice w/ Pork
- Szechuan Green Beans

My mouth is watering just thinking about it!

The vibe is upbeat and everyone who comes here is ready to have a good time. Beware of the long lines at popular hours. If you have a group of 6 or more, definitely make a reservation.
author: Emmy Q.

description: I went to Chubby Noodle almost 2 weeks ago for brunch. The food was decent but the service was sub par, which I understand on a busy day. The reason for this review is the aftermath. After getting home I realized that we were over charged by $50 for brunch. I called chubby noodle the day after and was told they would look into it. No call back. I follow up in a week and they said their finance person was on vacation and they promised they would get back to me the same day. Still it's been 2 days and no call back, so I'm writing this review. I find it absurd that I continue to have to follow up and also that it takes a finance person to issue a credit for us being over charged. Wish I could give negative stars. While the food was decent, I won't be going back because in the event something goes wrong it's a full-time job for me to remedy it. Terrible customer service.
author: Jordana W.

description: I was really craving some ramen style or any kind of Asian style soup on a chilly Sunday evening in the city but was disappointed to find out Chubby Noodle only serves at a certain time (don't ask me when cause I was pretty drunk with a big group of friends). We still chose to wait and be seated... ordered shrimp pad Thai and garlic noodles with an Asahi on the side, among other things. Food was great! Definitely hit and filled the spot, but boyyyyy was it a bit pricey. It was also pretty busy as the place is quite small and I'm sure it didn't help with how big our group was. I do wanna come back when they're serving noodles so I can say I got to try some!
author: Danya P.

description:
2.5 STARS

I really struggled with writing this review.

Why?

The staff rocked! They were so nice, attentive, and efficient but the food was so not the business. I was a fan of their North Beach location but it seems like they have shifted to more Americanized Pan Asian which IMO is hard to pull off well.

Over the weekend, we went to Chubby Noodle for their $37 Bottomless Dim Sum Brunch with a max of 4 boozy drinks (90 min max). Reservations accepted. I wasn't expecting stellar nor authentic dim sum given the area and because it's AYCE but for the $37 price tag, I at least expected it to be decent. Maybe dinner is a better reflection of the restaurant than their weekend brunch?

Of the 12 items offered on their bottomless weekend dim sum brunch menu, only two were good. The other two were mediocre, and the rest of the dishes were PF Chang and Elephant Bar-ish; commercialized, over-sauced, and super salty. The two guys I went with love salty foods but even they were complaining that it was so salty. And, sadly the dim sum and dumplings were worse than the Asian buffets in the Peninsula like Kome, Moonstar, and Beijing that charge $12-$15 for lunch. 

B O O Z Y  D R I N K S (4 max)
You get a choice of Cold tea (w/ nigori), Hoang mimosa (w/ Asian pear), or Rose sangria. I tried the Hoang mimosa: http://bit.ly/1xEXcdH which was nice and fruity but watered down from the ice. 

S O U P S  &  P O R R I D G E
*Breakfast Jook (http://bit.ly/1BB4SfW): GET THIS! You can never go wrong  with bacon and an egg with a runny yolk. Jook had a nice, creamy consistency.
*Hot & Sour Soup (http://bit.ly/1HAv7Ho): Too much white vinegar and not enough heat with an overload of white pepper.
*Wonton Soup (http://bit.ly/1tDyLYG): Wontons were nice and meaty but lukewarm broth was like sweet pho broth.

N O O D L E S
*Chilled Ramen (http://bit.ly/1xL8qPw): GET THIS TOO! Like a rendition of bibim naengmyeon (spicy korean cold noodles), it was refreshing and had great textures from the crisp veggies and kimchi. The runny yolk cut through the heat perfectly. 
*Chubby Chicken Chow Mein (http://bit.ly/1Ih4OV0): Nice presentation. Noodles were perfectly al-dente but too much soy so it was really salty. 
*Rice Cake in XO (http://bit.ly/14q6PBK): XO is a really pungent sauce made from fried fish and shrimp so it should be used sparingly. Again, too much sauce so it was really salty but noodle rolls were firm and tender.

D U M P L I N G S
*Sui [sic] Mai (http://bit.ly/1tK8AVY): Reminds me of the kind you get from TJ's freezer aisle. Wrapper fell apart upon picking up.
*Shrimp Dumpling (http://bit.ly/14q6kaW): Filling was ok but wrapper was thick and gummy. Wrapper fell apart upon picking up.
*Shanghai Dumplings (http://bit.ly/1FbsyOd): Mini baozi filled with over-sauced shredded BBQ chicken. Sorry, but this was a fusion fail. 

D I M  S U M
*Peking Duck: This pic says it all:  http://bit.ly/1tK8sWw.  I have a feeling they buy the ducks from a Chinatown and throw them in the deep fryer before serving.
*Salt & Pepper Shrimp (http://bit.ly/13TIkvJ): Undercooked and tasted like a salt and white pepper lick. 
*Kung Pao Wings (http://bit.ly/1Ih532q): Too salty and wings were not crispy. 

Again, the staff was great. Our young Asian waiter was a sweetheart. It was packed he and the other staff managed to quickly turn around orders and clear empty plates.

The ambiance is great for people in their young 20s: very "lively". For those over that scene, it was way too loud (music was blaring) and rowdy. Dude in the booth in back of us kept elbowing me in the neck. 

The space is good for groups as there were more communal tables and booths than two tops but space is cramped. 

Finding street parking can be hard so good luck. 

So who's down to go to Kome and clothesline poh pohs for their XLBs? I'm kidding...
author: Cherylynn N.

description: We came here for brunch on Saturday at like 2:30 ish and waited for 20-30 min for seating at the bar. It's $37 per person with bottomless drinks and 15 dimsum items to choose from for 90 minutes. There were three of us and we were ravenous so we pretty much ordered the entire menu. I really liked the salt and pepper shrimp, the breakfast jook, and the Peking duck buns. All the dumplings were really good as well but they pretty much ran out after we put our orders in. It's just such a good deal for delicious food and drinks. The mimosa of the day was made with cantaloupe juice which I didn't think I would like but it didn't have an overpowering melon flavor and I ended up with 1837392 refills. I also like that they play hip hop music so it's like a party brunch! I just can't get over how good of a deal it is! Will def be back!
author: Jennie C.

description: Okay, don't get me wrong. The food is delicious. I ordered the kobe beef chow mein, salt & peppa shrimp and the fried chicken. Everything tasted soooooo good! Why did I give them 3* then? The portions are insanely small (when comparing to the pictures on yelp. The noodles in the chow mein was great but there was barely any pieces of beef. What's the point of paying the $14 for beef-less chow mein?
author: Meraj C.

description:
Pros: really yummy food (the chilled ramen and the bok choy were my favorites), strong drinks (at least the sake tea was strong, the mimosa was pretty diluted), fun environment as long as you don't mind the noise

Cons: It's a little pricey (mandatory $37 brunch without tax or tip on the weekends, but it is bottomless), gets packed and so it can take a while to get the food you want, the noise is a little much if you're trying to talk to your friends
author: Lianne K.

description: Date night, girls night, staff meeting, hungover Sunday at the house... whatever it is cubby noodle is always a good idea. This has been my go to spot for a couple years. The food is delicious! Every.single.dish. They also Postmates if your feeling lazy :) If you decide to dine in the staff is always so lovely. Marc is usually there when we come in and he is Always very attentive and smiley :)
author: Alexa I.

description: Great spot - best noodles in town. Pork pao is awesome too. Sake cocktails are good as well.
author: Aaditya D.

description:
Chubby noodle has been at the top of our late night food options to try for months now. Tonight we finally had a good reason to make it out to the marina and opted to give it a try. We ordered pretty much everything on the menu just to try it all. 

Spicy garlic noodles - 4/5 - Not quite as good as the reviews made it out to be, but still enjoyable.
Chilled ramen noodles - 2/5
Chile prawns noodles - 2/5
Tuna poke - 3/5
Kung pow wings - 3/5
Bbq pork fried rice - 4/5 - This dish was loaded with meat and had a nice oily taste to it. When the leftover sauce from the ribs was poured on it I'd put it at 5/5.
Pork ribs - 4/5 - the ribs were not quite as tender as I'd like but the sauce was so tasty it made up for it.
Salt pepper prawns - 5/5 - Deshelled, nicely battered and a great tangy dipping sauce made this dish fantastic.

Normally, I'd give this place a 4/5 because I'm definitely a fan of their food and I would make this a regular spot to go to. Unfortunately the atmosphere was so abrasive and uncomfortable that I need to drop it down to a 3/5. The music is obnoxiously loud and was just non stop low quality hip-hop. I'm not sure if they think they're a club or something, but they should definitely take note that if you're almost empty at closing time on a Saturday night, you're not pulling off the club/bar vibe. They should scale it back and let their quality food carry them forward. Until then this place is at best "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description: 3.5 stars for brunch, 4 for dinner. The drinks at brunch were totally watered down and the food was decent - definitely not worth $50 bucks/person. That being said, their dinner is delicious! Highly recommend their spicy garlic noodles and tacos.
author: Mileen Z.

description: Wasn't too impressed. I know they hand make everything and the way everything was described sounded soooo good. But when i tasted it the first bite was great! But everything after just started to dull. And then it got heavy. Really really really heavy. It's a fun little place to try when you have a chance. It's laid back and i had fun here.
author: Leme K.

description:
I went here with my girlfriend for Sunday brunch at around 2pm. We actually went to their other location at first, but couldn't even find parking so we decided to try this one instead. When we were seated, we actually started out at the bar. This place is super crowded (we didn't have to wait at all, thank goodness), blasting with top 40's music, and very good vibe. I actually felt like I was at a day club because people were dancing and just having a good time. 

We didn't know that for brunch, they only have an option to pay $37 for 15 dim sum items (two of you means 30 items), and 4 drinks. We were very hesitant and almost didn't want to do that because that's A LOT, but we ended up going for it anyway. When I emphasize A LOT, it's not a joke! We probably got 17 dim sum items out of 30 and I honestly felt like I was pregnant eating so much but no doubt, their quality of food is top notch. The only thing I didn't really like were their dumplings but everything else was sooooo good. We ordered the rice cakes with X.O. sauce but they never brought it out to us. By the end, we were so full we didn't even want it anymore.

Overall, I think this place is so worth it for the price. $37 might sound a little too much when you look at the menu, but honestly, if you think about it and if you can eat a lot, $37 is REALLY good for the price. You get both food and drinks! 

Size wise, this place is pretty small so either go really early or later before they close for brunch at 3pm. I love love the atmosphere here and the staffs are very chill. Would definitely come back but probably with a group this time!
author: Anna L.

description:
I'd heard great things, though I must admit that the crazy loud music on a Monday night made me question when we first sat down. But hey, I don't have any other Asian fusion nightclub wanna be restaurants within walking distance of my house, so why not give it a try.

Glad I did! There were two of us, and the waitress kindly explained that everything was family style and that for 2 people she recommended 3-4 dishes. Being the hungry fatties that we were, we went with 4:

1. Chinese chicken salad: this was not my choice, had it not been for my dinner date I never would have ordered it. But so glad be did! It was delicious! The chicken was so fresh and tender, the sauce so perfect, the lettuce so tasty, I sacked every bite! I'd order this again in a heartbeat. 

2 spicy garlic noodles: despite the name, these are not, in fact, spicy. But they are full of flavor. So yum! A must for sure!

3. Chile prawn noodles: we were actually debating between this and the spicy garlic noodles when ordering, but when the waitress described them both to us we just had I order both. Glad we did! This dish is the chubby flat rice noodles that grace their sign, and so tasty. Delicious sauce. Amazing prawns. The waitress said it was quite spicy but we didn't think so. Very very good. 

4. Last but not least, the flounder. The fish itself was quite good, but the best part was actually the mushrooms and veggies that topped it. So tasty!

Great experience, good service, reasonably priced, and I'd order ever dish again. So happy this is now open in the Marina!
author: Krista S.

description:
The service was great and they played good music but the food was just "A-OK." I read so many great reviews I may have had high expectations going in and was a bit disappointed when the food was just regular. For the price and serving size (tapas style) it was way hyped up for me. 

We tried the Spicy Garlic Noodles, Korean Pork Tacos and Chinese Green Beans. Out of those I thought the green beans had the most flavor. We sat at a shared table and I saw a lot of people order the Poke so I would say try that. 

I would definitely recommend giving it a try. I think the dim sum brunch might be more my style. If other people wanted to go, I would definitely give it another try.
author: Ambriss R.

description: This place is the real deal. The marina bar scene meets delicious bowls of noodles. Always one of my go-to stops when I'm in the city and it never gets old.
author: Pratik P.

description: I didn't know noodles could be so great. Went to this place with my buddies when I was visiting a friend in San Francisco and it was delicious. I odered the garlic noodle with the friend chicken and it was perfection at its best. The soft, garlicky noodles mixed with the fried, crispy chicken was a great combo. It was so good it makes you wanna slap yo mama! The padthai and the chicken wings were also a hot. Would definitely come back here again and again. Oh yeah, really cute servers too.
author: Edwardson S.

description:
Oops! I did it again...I got way too drunk off of cheap champagne, fueled by the drunken desire to keep collecting the cute (but probably dirty) rubber ducks that come in each cocktail. 

You won't have trouble finding this place because they're the only place blaring hip hop on a Sunday morning in the Marina. That being said, you probably won't be able to hold a conversation here because the music is so loud. Initially I could have done without it, but then they 'Drunk in Love' twice and we were way too happy (and drunk) about it. 

The deal is all you can eat and all you can drink for $37. There are three cocktails and sapporo to choose from, and you can do sake for $5 (?) extra. We got two (or three? four?) rounds of free sake because it was our server's last day and she just DGAF. Shout out to you, you small, Asian spitfire. I alternated between the mimosa and the sangria--don't ask how many I had because I couldn't tell you. The drinks kept coming, even when they weren't requested, so we kept ordering more food. Overall nothing was too special. The rice cakes with XO sauce were spicy and sweet; a little too sweet for my taste. The best dish was the wontons, which come in a garlicky sauce. We essentially tried everything on the brunch menu and it was the only one that stood out. 

Atmosphere is A+ if you're looking to get Sunday funday ratchet. By default you get chopsticks, so if you're awful at chopsticks when you're drunk--or sober--be sure to ask for a fork before your speech starts getting slurred. The food is really nothing to rave about, but you can get past that with a few shots.
author: Christina D.

description: great spot love the vibes and all the music that's playing while I enjoy my delicious food! Pork tacos next level! More on the expensive side but worth every penny!
author: Jeff M.

description:
Visiting from Atlanta and couldn't imagine coming to SF and not having dim sum...found this place online as one of the best places in SF for brunch so my expectations were high......not only were they met, they were exceeded!

It was supposed to be a party of 4 but ended up being a party if 2. They were very seamless in handling that change. Before we were seated, the bartender was already offering us drinks, which was a good sign...

Once seated, out server came by and she was a fun-sized package of dynamite! She perpetuated the 'party' atmosphere they had going on as she explained the menu and process.  If you're looking for a quiet place for brunch, this isn't your spot. Tables are close, open kitchen and guests are loud and music is playing...but if you're going to dim sum for a quiet meal then you're already asking for disappointment! :)

$37 a person for all you can eat and all you can drink for 90 minutes is how this place works. If you can eat one of everything on the brunch menu then you are a rock star! All dishes are shareable. You have some standard dim sum dishes like shumai and bok choy/mushrooms marinated...but the majority of dishes are dim sum-esque dishes  but might not be on the menu at traditional dim sum shops. My favorites were the duck and the cold ramen. As for the drinks, we started off with pear mimosas, moved to sangrias and finished off with a few cold teas which were a great end cap to our meal.

Everyone on the staff came by our table at least once to drop off food, clear dirty plates, replace drinks or to just check on us which made for an overall great experience. 

This place gets the highest recommendations from me and will definitely come back during my next visit to the Bay Area.
author: Eugene J.

description: So good! We had a lot of amazing food in San Fran, but this was by far one of our best. Such a great vibe (reggae music and cool art), yummy food, and the best sake flight I've ever had. Be sure to get the coconut sake
author: Kirsty S.

description:
We LOVE this spot, great food at an affordable price, fun atmosphere.

The tacos are a must!
author: Brice M.

description: We were here for the Prix fixe brunch. Amazing food, freshly prepared for each table , bottomless drinks. We had mimosas and a light sangria. Choose 13 dishes for $39 each. Sounds pricey but the portions are large and the food fabulous. Loved the shechuan green beans, pickled veggies, pork dumplings, salt shrimp, Korean wings. It was so good . they say you have 1 1/2 hours to eat. We were stuffed much sooner than that. They take reservations.  So glad we found this place on our recent visit to SF.
author: Roberta M.

description: This place was so good.  You have to be comfortable with a loud, manic atmosphere. Food was great!
author: Tien R.

description:
Went to Chubby Noodle for a late lunch with 3 of my girlfriends! We had a reservation and were seated immediately. Our drink orders came out quickly and we never had to track anyone down to get our next round. 

One of the girls has a mild shell-fish allergy so our waiter made sure our group got loads of options everyone could eat! We basically had EVERYTHING on the menu, and 2 of some things (1 with chicken, 1 with shrimp). 

Everything we had was FANTASTIC! There wasn't a single thing I didn't like. I also loved that a mini rubber duck comes in every drink! Super fun and original! 

Our waiters were very nice and attentive. I even got one to take our photo with my Polaroid (he was a bit hesitant)

I definitely plan on coming back next time I'm in the city!
author: Niki G.

description: Stumbled upon this little gem after being disappointed by the menu options at another place down the road, and we will DEFINITELY put this on our list to revisit every time we are in town!!! Ordered the BBQ fried rice, salt & pepper shrimp, and pork ribs. Everything was to die for, especially the ribs!! Great customer service and very efficient! We sat down, ordered, ate and paid in less than an hour!
author: Lauren C.

description:
I guess part of the meaning of the name Chubby Noodle stems from how chubby you feel after grubbing down on the food. They have a pretty simple menu, and both locations seem to always be packed. I stopped into the Marina location for a to-go order last night. The music is loud but it's good music so that really shouldn't be a problem? Why are people complaining? You go out to eat, not talk the entire meal LOL.

-The popular Spicy Garlic noodles weren't actually that spicy :/ so don't be fooled. I think a lot of these people leaving high reviews just don't know what spicy is. Nonetheless, the noodles were still good. I was complaining about them costing 10 dollars but of course come to find out I couldn't even finish the whole carton in one sitting LOL so that's good. 

-The Chubby Chicken entree is also 10 dollars. That price is actually pretty steep for the amount of chicken you end up getting, but at least the chicken was good paired with the sauce. The pieces had little to no fat which is what I like. And yes they are boneless. I also got the cucumber salad which was just okay. 

However, it was a big disappointment (and the reason this review is 3 stars instead of 4) to find out at the last minute that there are no forks, only chopsticks. Or maybe there are no to-go forks. Either way it's disappointing and annoying, being how clearly not everyone in America knows how to use chopsticks. So I'm supposed to just up and immediately learn how to use chopsticks in less than 2 mins when I'm starving?? What are we, in Kill Bill vol. 2?  I debated going to one of the hotels nearby and asking for a fork but I thought that would be tacky so, lucky for Chubby Noodle I managed quite well with the chopsticks. 

I'll be back, but I guess I'll come prepared with FORKS. Maybe I'll stand around and pass them out to people who are also caught by surprise.
author: Marquis A.

description: A1 choice for the spot in SF, oh man chicken fingers and chow mein, FIRE! Just sit down and enjoy, keep ordering more and more
author: Roy T.

description:
2.5 really. I'm sure this restaurant fits the needs and satisfies others, but just didn't match my taste buds. 
Had relatively high expectations considering other establishments that serve a similar menu have tasty and well executed dishes. 
We had the salmon sashimi, Garlic noodles, and King Pao wings dishes. Everything was never in balance to my taste buds. Either too spicy, bland or both. 
Nothing else to comment other than the wings were tiny. 
Willing to try this place again though, the dishes still sound delicious so perhaps it's just the execution.
author: Patrick M.

description: Good but I get an unnatural snarl on my lip when I think about the grotesque 4th grade imagery of two ding dongs fumbling at each other's genitalia on the bathroom wall. No volume of pole grinding tune can bring me back in touch with my body's desire to consume, no matter how good the food...
author: Liz S.

description: I love Chubby Noodle. Obviously their pork tacos are fab as well as their garlicky street noodles. Came here for brunch on Mother's Day and it was boozy and amazing. We sat at the bar reluctantly but ended up preferring it. I have tried, at this point, most items on the menu and nothing fails. I do think their sake is kind of overpriced for what it is but not so much to be a gripe. All in all I'd give an A+.
author: Ryan J.

description: Always a fun time at Chubby Noodle. They consistently have great food, great drinks, friendly staff, and of course..excellent hip hop music. My latest experience warranted a review because, although they slightly inconvenienced us by asking us to change our rezo to the Marina location, they more than made up for it with free bottles. Shoutout to Jackie. This is definitely one of the best ways to do bottomless in SF. You. Will. Get. Lit
author: Myles S.

description:
I've been driving around the City for the past year and some of my riders have gone here and I decided to try it out on a late night when I was starving.  Mistake.  For some reason I thought this was going to be a place with lots of noodle choices -- it ain't.  Pretty short menu, only really two noodle dishes -- garlic noodles and, what I ordered, chow mein.   Chow mein was just 'ok', nothing special, not worth $12.  I agree with Edna in her review -- kinda weird to have fried noodles topping a noodle dish.   

I agree that the music is a bit much, and the service is not warm & friendly, just ok, at least when I went late-night.

This might be perfect for some diners, but not me.
author: Merrick W.

description:
Man, what a great new spot in the marina! Not exactly for the carb (or waistline) conscious, but it's so worth it! 

I came here after a run with my friend and we worked up quite the appetite. We ordered the green papaya salad, the poke, the fried rice and spicy garlic noodles. Everything really hit the spot, especially the noodles. It's a very simple dish, but the combination of the chewy noodles, the spice and slight sweetness just rounds out the dish. 

I also tried their tea cooler, which is the house special cocktail and liked it. Not for the faint of heart, it's very ginger-y, but good. 

The vibe here is laid back and you feel the energy buzzing in the air with the friendly staff. I'll definitely be back!
author: Alice W.

description:
The Food is amazing, the service is phenomenal, the environment is just nostalgic with 90's hip hop music. 

I went for Brunch on Saturday 01/21/17 during the woman's march, and the restaurant was packed but definitely worth the wait, fortunately we did not wait long 25 min, and again the service is phenomenal they have the most attentive staff. The host made sure we were seated within the wait time he told us about in the beginning, our server took care of everything for us kept the food coming recommended the best items, and our drink server was so nice and made sure to keep the drinks coming lol all of this for under $50.00!!! All you can eat dim sum and bottomless mimosas top 5 top 5!

WARNING make sure to come mentally and physically prepared to EAT, I was in a food comma for hours but I cannot wait until I come back to SF and eat here again
author: Priscilla R.

description:
I wished there was an option to give 0 stars. Businesses like Chubby Noodles do not deserve anything more than that. Their reservation system is inefficient (there's ONE person in charge of taking all reservations), their workers do not communicate with each other, and they laughed when I asked to put my name down on a waitlist.  

I tried to make reservations and sent them a 'reservation inquiry' through their website over the weekend; I got a call back the next day (they don't check emails over the weekend, I get it). The associate left a voice message letting me know that the spot for my party is available and to call back to confirm. I called back immediately, only to be greeted with a voicemail that was too full to accept any more messages. I called them again later that day but the next associate told me he wasn't in charge of reservations and to call back between 10-2pm. I decided to submit another reservation inquiry. I got a call back today letting me know they are fully booked for the Marina location. When I explained my frustration and the situation with the reservation guy, there was no apology for the inconvenience and he chuckled when I asked to put my name down in case they had any cancellation. His exact words, "Ha! Well, we don't have a waitlist, it would be really long if we did. Your best option is to call us back to see if anyone cancelled."
author: Lilian D.

description:
While I guess this restaurant could be "hip" or "cool" for some folks (admittedly, the octopus mural on the ceiling is neat and the service was warm), the music was way too loud (I was seated under one of the speakers) AND I left feeling really hungry because they botched my order twice and ultimately failed to find a solution. 

When ordering, I asked if the chubby chicken noodle would be spicy and was assured that it would not be. When it comes out, it is clearly spicy, so they take it back to re-make it. Bring it out a second time: still spicy. I was also assured that the green beans would not be spicy: came out spicy! In fact, almost every dish my table ordered was spicy! The only thing I could eat some of was the fried rice (which was decent). At least the waiter had the courtesy to check in to see if things were ok, but not coming here again.
author: Jan Z.

description:
Wow! Delicious! 

Stopped in with a friend and was seated right away (around 8:30pm). I ordered a huge Sapporo (it was the largest can I've ever seen). We started off with the kim chi, papaya salad, then had the garlic noodles and hot wings. Everything was so yummy. The salad was spicy but that's normal. Their housemade kim chi was awesome. I can see why this place is so popular. Would love to come back for dinner again!
author: Katie Anne N.

description: The food was delicious. I was pleasantly surprised by the flavor of our dish. What ruined everything was that just prior to receiving our food we were asked to move to a different table because someone had made a reservation and requested that table. I thought, all the tables are the same size and are near the window...maybe a couple reserved it for their anniversary or something. Maybe that's where they proposed to each other. My party of four pack up our drinks and moved one table over along the window. To my surprise, a woman came in with her two young children. I don't know who she was, maybe the owner, or a friend of the owner, but it doesn't matter. The table had no soecial meaning for her or her kids who were clearly under 10. I was so offended. Every customer should be treated the same. Little to no apology from staff either. Won't be back.
author: K.V. J.

description: This is my go to place whether I dine in or order. Love the spicy garlic noodles! Ordered from here a bunch of times and never been disappointed :)
author: Priyanka B.

description: Pretty big fan of the food here. The garlic noodles and chicken wings are awesome. I dined in the restaurant with friends on the weekend and the music was fun and the scene was lively but a bit much for a casual night out so we generally get takeout.
author: Jessica F.

description:
One of my favorite brunches in SF. It's incredibly fun and lively - good 90s / 2000s music; who doesn't love $39 all you can eat and drink!? Beware of the cold tea drink - it's made with vodka and strong :) the mimosas usually have a tropical juice that isn't orange with is a nice change and they also offer sapporos and sangria - who doesn't love a mix or match? 

The jook, wonton soup dumplings, kung pao chicken wings, and siu mai are all delicious. the peking duck is hit or miss and the chilled ramen isn't my friend group's favorite. 

Is this authentic dim sum? hell no, for that goto the Richmond. is the food perfect? No, but some of it is very, very good. They're fast to refill drinks and you really get your money's worth in 90 minutes. And it's one of the best and most fun places to get your SF day drinking started right!
author: Lucas S.

description: I went here with a group of friends for the all you can eat brunch option at noon on a Saturday. We were supposed to be a party of 7 but were instead six; however we were seated at a table that could comfortably seat 4. The cramped seating and music that was 50% beyond too loud made for a very uncomfortable experience. The food was nothing to write home about. The standouts were the szechuan green beans, the chicken wraps, and the chubby chow mein. All the other food (we tried everything on the brunch menu) was mediocre at best. Food service was okay; we had empty plates sit for a while before being swapped out but they were busy so I understand that. What Is incomprehensible is how poor the beverage service was. We were given one waiter for food who was sociable and competent, but our separate waiter for drinks was truly abysmal. He started out on the wrong foot by bringing a whole slew of wrong drinks to our first round, and continued to bring incorrect drinks when asked for drinks beyond the "mimosa" and "sangria" that were fifty percent melted ice and served from pitchers he would tote around and spill from (side note, don't wear white shoes, my friend who was sitting on the end of the had his feet stepped on repeatedly due to the cramped table, and since the servers didn't care when the plates they were toting were dripping sauce onto the floor, which I saw happen multiple times, his shoes were filthy by the end of the brunch). On the drink front, the cold tea is actually decent and the only thing that tastes like it has actual booze in it. All in all a very disappointing experience when you consider you could have spent the fifty and change dollars this experience will run you on any of the many unlimited brunch options available to you.
author: Ethan N.

description:
Holy cow anyone and everyone should go here. We went for bottomless brunch on a Saturday and the wait was about 45 min but well worth it. The minute you walk in you are offered the choice between four creative Asian inspired cocktails. 

Highly recommend letting them continuously bring out popular food until you're stuffed to the brim. Pace yourself. 90 minutes of bottomless brunch is a marathon not a sprint
author: Lauren F.

description: Their portal service took my credit card information and didn't actually communicate my order to the restaurant. When I arrived to pick up, I provided my info and was told it'd be right out. I waited fifteen minutes to be told that, actually, they didn't have any order from me. And my payment submitted. Restaurant didn't offer to comp and didn't apologize for their shitty portal or that I had waited for nonexistent items in their hot and loud restaurant... not to mention they lied about the order when I first arrived. Frustrating, to say the least.
author: Shauny U.

description: Chubby Noodle is always on our list for dinner when we visit San Francisco. We absolutely love this place, we always get the chilled noodles. Appetizers are always delicious and i don't think there is a single item on the menu that isn't delicious and trust me we've tried everything!! The bartenders are very friendly and after a few min of conversation he made us a custom drink based on what we like and he was spot on. Good drinks and amazing food, you can't go wrong here!
author: Paul M.

description:
I've been curious about Chubby Noodle since we arrived in SF. Besides the cute name and extremely close proximity to our hotel, the reviews and pictures of the food appealed to me. We didn't get a chance to try it until our final night in the city but I am so glad we tried it and made it our last meal in SF.  It was delicious and I will come back again on our next trip. 

Initially we wanted to eat in the restaurant but the heat from the kitchen and the lateness of the hour didn't agreed with our baby.  The restaurant is long and skinny with a handful of high top tables, a bar, booths, and a handful of low top tables in the very back. We chose a booth so we could sit by the window and let the baby look at traffic. I'm going to get real - folks with a little more girth would do well to consider the tables. The booths are just a little too narrow and squished for my taste but this may be because I had my baby on my lap. Between the two of us, he was just a few inches away from the table so it felt uncomfortable. Just an observation - I am well aware of the space limitations on everything in this city. 

Our very nice and accommodating server provided us with some water while we waited. My husband chose the Kobe beef chow menu and I chose the spicy garlic noodles with an addition of fried chicken at our server's suggestion. The wait for our food was about 10-15 mins, pretty reasonable with it being made to order right in front of me. I loved all the smells in the kitchen - it took me right to my dad's kitchen (he's a Cantonese chef). Even my husband commented it smelled just like my parents' kitchen. Once we got everything back to the hotel (extra sambal requested), time to dig in.  I am a fan of chili-spicy so I usually request additional spice to tune the dish to my taste after I've had a first bite. The fried chicken was delicious - salty, Asian spices with a hint of sweet. I expected just a few pieces in my meal but there were at least 8-10 pieces, about 1 x .5 inches - decent sizes!  The breaking makes me think of Taiwanese popcorn chicken so that may be their inspiration. Either way, they were yummy (more so dipped in sambal but that is based on your own preference). Finally got to my noodles and they also were very good - love the combination of peppers, garlic, soy sauce, and egg noodles any day and this did not disappoint. I will say I would found the dish to be a little bit more bland without the addition of the chicken. It wasn't quite to my spice level so I had to add sambal but that's me.  I would say on a scale of 1 - 10 with 10 being burn your face off spicy, this was more like a 2 or 3. 

I tried my husband's kobe beef noodles and liked those as well - especially the Szechuan paste. It was a little sweet which made me think they must incorporate soy sauce and mirin in it as well.  I used to think chili ran in my veins but it probably is more soy sauce. I found the piece of beef I tasted to be slightly chewy but that doesn't bother me. 

My husband and I are chopstick users so it was nice to see chopsticks on every table (forks only by request) and when I asked for chopsticks to-go, they were already in the bag - no forks included. I feel like in such a diverse city not offering forks/spoons/knives right always encourages patrons to eat the meals with the preferred utensils. 

Overall the meal was delicious, even as take out. Next time we're in town I'd like to try their stir fried green beans (they smelled AMAZING) and the AYCE dim sum on the weekends.
author: Julie W.

description:
Oh Chubby Noodle. I love you. This is a super fun place to go on the weekend with some friends. The ambiance is cool and fun. I've been here twice for birthday parties. And I've also been here with just the boyfriend.

With the birthday menu, it's around $40 a person and a prefix. Be warned though, both times we all did a lot of sake bombs and ended up each spending $100+

Papaya salad- 2/5 I'm not a papaya person, so that's why the low rating. My boyfriend loves it. 
Spicy Garlic Noodles- 5/5 You can't go to Chubby Noodle and not get noodles. They are delicious and fresh. 
Korean Pork Tacos- 5/5 These are great. They have so much flavor, but they are super salty and I am a salt lover. 
Tuna Poke- 5/5 Another must order. This dish is so good. The tuna is super fresh and I am obsessed with the chips. 
Salt & Pepper shrimp- 4/5 I liked this. The shrimp is fried and has a nice light batter. 
Chubby Fried Chicken- 5/5 My favorite dish. The chicken is so good and juicy. The dipping sauce is freaking amazing.

Go with friends on the weekend and listen to them bump old school, Hip Hop and R&B. Just be award of how much sake you drink. It will cost a pretty penny.
author: Gabrielle C.

description:
When you're not in the mood for a traditional american brunch, you have to go to Chubby Noodle. Okay, what brunch place in San Francisco takes reservations?! Eating brunch at 11:30AM and not having to line up at 9:00AM sounds good to me. 

So, for about $37+Tax&Tip you get the bottomless dimsum and drinks on the weekend. Don't be shy and make sure you try everything on the menu. It's a lot of fun going with a group because everyone gets to try a little bit of everything. Make sure you're ready to drink too, because the staff drops off glasses of mimosas at your table before you can even put your hand up for another one.

A couple of my favorite dishes include the roasted duck with steam buns and the breakfast jook! Oh the breakfast jook, a rice porridge with a perfectly cooked egg and bacon. The asian pear mimosas were soooo good. Very refreshing!

Mark and the rest of the staff at Chubby Noodle definitely know how to get people going on a Sunday morning. The service was outstanding and so polite. You can tell that they really enjoy the work place.
author: Rae Dawne G.

description: Loud, party atmosphere at night.  Spicy garlic noodles are somewhat oily, but the barbeque pork in the noodles are decent. Good fried rice. Most dishes are somewhat spicy.
author: Alison D.

description: I think I'm obsessed. Fun dim sum style Asian fusion place. Such a fun atmosphere and they play drake and tlc so it's easily the best place I've ever been. Loved everything about it and had a blast. Little pricey, but I imagine brunch is more than worth the price. We got the garlic noodles, sashimi, tacos and wontons and that was way more than enough food. We also had the sweetest waitress known to man who was sweet enough to give me a birthday shot (25 woohoo). Seems like a fun place to come on a Sunday morning or Friday night with all your friends. Also they have sake on tap which is rad.
author: Melinda G.

description:
Amazing food. We got the Szechuan green beans (shockingly good),  Korean pork tacos (must have), salt and pepper shrimp, sizzlin fish, shrimp pad Thai, garlic noodles (top entree),  kimchi (very spicy), and papaya salad (cool and refreshing) -- there were 4 of us. We finished everything. 

So delicious. The loud hip hop makes it a fun atmosphere. Cozy seating. A little pricey but worth it.
author: Alexis A.

description: Chubby Noodle is a breath of fresh air in the preppy (generally uppity) neighborhood it inhabits. I love the laid back ambiance and the music. Our server was friendly and attentive. The food is really tasty and they offer a pretty large variety of noodles and other options. The Korean tacos are delicious as well as the spicy garlic noodles.
author: Sara K.

description:
Please note: This review is solely based on the service. I feel the need to type up this review because everyone should know how terrible their service is. I was with a group of 4 this past Friday night around 8pm, we expected a long wait but that didn't bother us. We waited for about a good twenty minutes and the hostess sat couple in this huge table for about 6 people. I'm pretty sure we were next in line...I let it go because I was having great conversations with my party. A few more minutes went by...

We're near the entrance of the restaurant, not blocking the exit at all, and the hostess goes AND I QUOTE:
 "It's gonna be more than a 40 minute wait. Why don't you all, go like, to the a bar and get a drink or something. There's plenty on this street." 

She didn't say it politely. She was rude, condescending, and had an overall negative vibe. As soon as she said that, I was so over Chubby Noodle. No matter how good the food is, I'm not willing to be talked like that. This hostess, whose name I wasn't able to get, should know that she is indeed working in the customer service industry. Customer service, she should look it up and learn a few things or too.
 
Don't come here. The hostess will tell you to walk your ass over to a bar. But good thing she did, we went to the Tacolicious down the street and it was outright delicious.
author: Stefany Z.

description:
It's Ace Wasabi meets pan-Asian food. The food is solid and by 8 pm on a Monday night, it was packed. It's a bit loud for an intimate conversation between friends as 90's hip hop thumps in the background. 

The food was okay. We had the tuna poke (with shrimp chips), the Korean pork tacos, bok choy and spicy prawns / noodle dish. My favorite dishes were the tuna poke and the bok choy. The spicy prawns / noodle dish was pretty bland and one note - about half a dozen shrimp with a mass of rice noodles and bean sprouts. The Korean pork tacos were okay but the tortillas they were on were hard and detracted from the taco filling. 

Drinks - wine in particular - were on the pricey side and the pours were inconsistent. The first glass of wine was half the pour of the second glass of wine - I guess I'm happy the second glass was a more generous pour?
author: Wendy L.

description: My friend and I came here around 6pm on a Friday night and only waited ~10 minutes to be seated. This place definitely has that Marina vibe- the music is good but very loud (we had to yell across the table to be heard). Everything we ordered was delicious! The korean pork tacos were probably my favorite, but the duck lettuce wraps and garlic noodles were great as well. Portions were large, and we left extremely full. The bottomless brunch looks awesome- will have to try that next time!
author: Chloe Z.

description:
I really liked the hip hop/rap music and the space! It made for a fun dinner :D The service was good and I was actually kind of impressed how our server remembered our order of 8 dishes without writing anything down. The food itself wasn't anything AMAZING, but there were a few standout dishes: the spicy garlic noodles and the tacos! The noodles were the perfect amount of spiciness and the meat and tortillas of the tacos were really yummy (probably my favorite dish).

The chow mein wasn't anything special and I think they just used the same kind of noodles in the chow mein and garlic noodles. The fried rice was a little bland for my tastes, and the tune poke was also just average. Overall, I would still go to Chubby Noodle again because of the good service, fun atmosphere, and those few key dishes!
author: Grace C.

description:
This was a great place to go to dinner before catching a show in Fort Mason. We were a group of four which would have meant about a 20 minute wait, but there were enough seats open at the bar so we grabbed those. The bartender took our order and he was friendly and helpful, giving us tips to navigate the menu. He even let us sample shots of sake!

We ordered the Korean pork tacos, spicy garlic noodles with fried chicken, and duck wraps. Everything was delicious and affordable, especially for hungry stomachs.
author: Ariana C.

description:
Came here for a Saturday brunch with a friend - we were seated at the bar. We proceeded to basically order everything on the menu, so I'll just do a few one-liners about each. 

Wonton Soup - Avoid. Their soup came out lukewarm and tasted funny. 

Chilled Ramen - Get. Slightly on the spicy side for those who can't take spiciness (because of the kimchi), but the fried egg (which they leave runny) balances out the strong kimchi taste and gives the dish a nice texture. 

Breakfast Jook - Also avoid. Not sure what's up with Chubby noodle and it's soup-based dishes, but none of them were good (and are always lukewarm... see above "Wonton Soup")

Chubby Chow Mein - GET. We actually got 2 orders of this. The description of "egg noodles and vegetables" doesn't do it justice. Great house sauce. 

Peking Duck Steam Bun - Comes with four, with very lean meat (which I like, even if that's not how peking duck should be). I ate all of them. Slightly oily. Get. 

Shanghai Dumplings - Scallions are not cut very thinly/finely, but otherwise great. Get this also. 

Kunpao Chicken Wings - We got 2 orders of this - you should too. 

Shrimp Dumplings - Strictly average. Depends on if you like shrimp I guess.

+ points for the hilarious menu
+ points for service
- points for the "mimosas" that were basically just sparkling wine and nothing else
- points for how raucous it gets (Though I get that it's a pretty popping restaurant on Saturday mornings, there was a bachelor/bachelorette party of some going on right next to the bar, and people were taking shots and leaving their shot glasses on my napkin, or leaning on the bar literally inches away from my food)

Expect the cost to be ~$45+ after tax and tip
author: Matthew L.

description:
Very mediocre food by my standards. I'm a little forgiving since it's "asian fusion", but honestly, your money is better spent elsewhere.

I'm disappointed by their service -- it took 20 minutes to seat us when they said it would only be 10.

To start, service was very poor even before rush hour. We weren't seated by order; the servers let a family of 4 cut us for a booth... when literally all of their seats were by booths. Just by instinct, this was a bad sign.

When we were seated, it was around 6, and a nice waitress came, recommended some wines and we went with a red from Peju winery, as well as their in-house sake. Both drinks were okay, with the in-house Chubby sake being the stronger of the two.

For food, we went off of recommendations on yelp.

(++) Sashimi Ceviche

Pretty decent, but $11 for overtly salty and slightly too spicy sashimi ruined the pure flavor of the fish. It was a rip off being mostly spice and soy sauce. C'mon. 

(++++) Spicy Garlic Noodles

This was perhaps the only dish that saved them from a 1 star review. These noodles were well-seasoned and lightly saucy, really hittin' the spot by a stream of flavors in every bite.

(-) Korean Pork Tacos

Our waitress was for some reason, overtly excited, maybe perhaps cause she was Caucasian, on how we had to try the Korean Pork Tacos... which were a big let down. It was literally 2 flour tortillas, some pork and spicy mayo with cilantro... where's the kimchi.... or anything else? For $11, you aren't getting your money's worth here either.

I noticed as we finished our table, and the restaurant began to fill, it's more of a place to get shit-faced and not care about the food.... I saw groups and groups doing shots and just eating this half-decent food... In truth, it's very disappointing despite being hyped up.
author: Davinci L.

description:
This place came recommended from a friend and the vibe didn't disappoint. The presentation of the food and the unassuming hipster decor was on point. 

But two unfortunate things happened. 

The waiter suggested that my sister and I order 4 dishes when 2 would've been plenty (in hindsight). And we were both tormented by a stomach ache within 30 minutes after finishing and leaving. 

I'd like to believe we were unlucky, so if given the opp would try this place again. My advice on ordering, don't get the chubby noodles.
author: Eric M.

description: Food is great, but I was literally coughing for the entire dinner, as were my friends. The smoke was making us all cough because it is such tight quarters and little ventilation.
author: Meagan M.

description: Tidy table for 2 and great place for people of  3 and more. If you love fusion styles of chinese, thai and korean food, this is your place. Price is reasonable.
author: Sanguan L.

description:
Tasty Food. Good Music. Cute Spot. That being said, they probably should have offered to take the pad thai off our bill. We literally ordered almost the entire menu and it was obvious we did not care for the pad thai. It was beyond sweet and saucy..aggressively sweet. All of our plates were pretty much licked clean. The hostess even asked and we politely told her that we loved ALMOST everything except that dish. Im not clear why you would ask if you didnt intend on a remedy. 
We paid our bill and left. It was almost a home run.
author: Karena H.

description: Can't wait to go back. Delicious food despite the brunch time limit and cool as F* experience. Destroyed so much grub and drinks here. Just wished the soju wasn't so plane Jane flavor but the staff managed to make them tasty. Great service experience too. A must brunch spot if you and in SF, but good luck finding availability book a table ahead!
author: Eduardo S.

description: I loved this place.  Ok Jalapeño calimari was excellent, unique flavor, hot and sweet.  Duck taco.. 5 stars, so good and again a different take on some usual stuff.  Pad thai, garlic noodle, ribs... all so yummy.  Price is great... between like $12 and $17 a plate, great to share.  Service was amazing.  We had a large party and the waiter MARK! comes over and says "I heard someone say they were a vegetarian" he made suggestions and modified things to have no fish sauce.  He was super on everything, went back again tonight A+ again and had Mark again.  So nice to get yummy food and great service all in one spot.
author: edward g.

description: A friend brought me here when I was visiting San Francisco, and the food was absolutely delicious! The noodles and the wings are a must order, and the vibe is super chill and fun. If you are looking for a laid back, but good meal in San Francisco I would come here.
author: Shraddha M.

description: Unbelievable. The ribs blew my proverbial tits off. Salt and pepper shrimp was killer. Awesome music. Great staff. 10/10 would very highly recommend. Probably coming back tomorrow.
author: Luke W.

description: Gorgeous interior, hip vibe, hip service. The house sake is amazingly drinkable and comes in a giant carafe. The spicy noodles are fantastic.
author: Will D.

description: Came here for lunch on a beautiful and sunny Sunday afternoon. Treated to friendly service (thanks Vince!), delicious food, and some unfiltered hip hop music blasting from every corner of this little storefront. One whole wall of windows gives you great access to people watching on Lombard. This is a great Asian fusion option, would definitely come back for brunch!
author: Chinwe N.

description:
This review is only for a Caviar delivery.

Saw this place on Caviar and decided to give it a try since it looked like some pretty good Chinese food. I got the BBQ pork fried rice which was pretty good but nothing amazing. Just tasted like any other typical fried rice? They were really generous with their BBQ pork servings though so I liked that. It was also pretty decently priced--I think it was probably only about $9 or so and it was a completely full take out box so in terms of how filling it was and good it was, it was pretty solid. Wouldn't necessarily ever crave this, but it's good. 

The fried chicken take-out portion is pretty small, fyi

tldr; okay Chinese food from Caviar, nothing special
author: Jasmine X.

description:
I saw in my feed the other day about Chubby Noodle launching their bottomless dim sum brunch this weekend for $37 pp.  I wasn't expecting much, but I thought why not, so I booked a table for yesterday at 10:30 for us through Yelp's SeatMe.  The first available reservations were for 10:15, & we arrived then & two other parties but were told to sit at the bar while they finish getting ready.  Boozy drinks were also included and you can order up to 4.  We started off the hoang mimosa.  It was refreshing but not sweet nor tart nor overly boozy.  Loved the cute mini rubber ducky floating in it.  Later on we also sampled a rose sangria.  I usually don't enjoy rose wine but this was light and not too floraly, with a hint of the fruit as well. 

We were seated at a small table a few minutes before our reservation.  There were 15 dishes on the menu and 4 included boozy drinks and about 3 other wines you can pay an additional fee for.  We started off with orderinf the breakfast jook, hot & sour soup, Peking duck, shrimp dumpling & chicken Shanghai dumpling.  It seems that our waitress got mixed up & put in an order of the wonton soup instead of hot & sour, which was actually ok with me since I'm not a fan of hot & sour, sorry dear!  The broth was very light and had bean sprouts in it, kind of reminded me of pho thought it was a light duck broth.  There were also bok choy and three delicious delicate wontons.  Next came the star of the meal, the breakfast jook!  I always love a good bowl of traditional plain jook, but this was by far the best bowl of jook ever (sorry grandparents!).  Everyone has their jook consistency preference, but I like mine slightly chunky with enough broth (so not just chunks of the rice but not that liquidy either), and this one was this.  Plus the over easy egg, smoked bacon & fried bits of onion - HEAVENLY!  I was so tempted to get another bowl.  They paced the dishes well and we were always able to order more though there were a couple snafus but it's understandable as this was their first day of rolling this out.  After a little bit came the Peking duck buns.  The buns were so fluffy!  The duck was roasted though was way more fatty than meat but was a good attempt on a traditional dish.  Some of the skin was a little more soggy than crispy.  Half way during the meal they told us that they were out of the shrimp dumpling but asked if we wanted to order the pork and beef siu Mai instead and we agreed.  Next up: the salt and pepper shrimp.  I liked how it wasn't overly fried like it typically is in most Chinese restaurants but a teeny bit on the bland side.  The chicken chow mein was hot with chilies and jalapeños in it.  We liked how they put the fried onion strings in there and there was plenty of chicken in it as well.  The Shanghai chicken dumpling was my least favorite, I think due to the ginger and thick wrapper.  The pork and beef siu Mai, though the wrapper was very thin (filling fell out after first bite), this was excellent.  Great flavor from the meat combo & I would take this over the traditional shrimp, pork and mushroom filling.  Wrapping up the meal, we were told that the shrimp dumplings were now available and asked if we wanted them and we said sure.    We ordered their popular kung pao wings.  They were crisply fried and were covered in this spicy sauce.  Spiciest second to the chow mein actually.  I think it's just that they still needed time to prep some of the dumplings after opening.  The shrimp dumplings were shaped differently than the normal ha gaw, they were shaped like the scallop dumplings you normally see.  Again, thin wrapper, plump bits of shrimps formed together.  Lastly we closed it out with the shrimp fried rice.  Our waitress accidentally put in for the XO sauce rice cakes, but the she and the staff were very apologetic and got our fried rice out to us shortly.  The fried rice had lots of big shrimps and was simple with eggs, rice and some green onions.  We also liked how it wasn't greasy.  What I really like about CN too is their assortment of sauces they give you - a green onion soy sesame oil blend, the chili sauce and what I think was a very mild version of their hot mustard sauce.  

I don't think everything that our stomachs allowed us to sample was amazing, but the brunch deal was a great deal especially with the four alcoholic drinks included.  I would definitely come back and try to sample some things that I didn't get to and some of our favorites like the breakfast jook, wings & siu mai!  We were pleasantly surprised by Chubby Noodle and I know that after this weekend, the bottomless dim sum brunch will be running so smoothly.  I would be open to coming back to trying their dinner menu as well.  Friendly staff, comforting eats, cute minimal decor, & good wine based cocktails.  CN staff- Can you please have the breakfast jook available all day?  It's foodgasmic!  3.5 but rounded up to 4 stars, better than some other fusion restaurants.
author: Cat C.

description: This place has beast noodles, fried rice, and Korean tacos. Free delivery too!!! A must order
author: michael m.

description:
I'm a HUGE foodie and I love Asian food and to sum it up, I am obsessed with this place!

It gets pretty packed at night, especially on the weekends. So every time I go, I avoid going during "dinner hour." It can also get pretty loud due to the crowds, but if you don't mind that sort of thing, then you're good!

Their tuna poke is the BEST and is served with shrimp chips. Spicy garlic noodles are a MUST (we always add pork to our noodles). Their pork tacos are full of flavor and instead of a tortilla, I think they use roti bread which makes it amaziiinggg! The sauce served with the pork tacos is addicting too. And last, their wings are spicy and crispy and delicious!!!

I ate at Chubby Noodle 4 times last week. And they never disappoint! It's better and better every time I go.
author: Chisholm T.

description:
A group of 4 of us were strolling around the Marina on a Saturday evening looking for a spot to eat.  We had heard great things about Chubby Noodle and tried to walk in sans-reservation.  The wait was going to be 45+min, so we went elsewhere.  That said, my interest was definitely piqued.

I came back with my wife on a slower Sunday - again without reservation.  Luckily, we were seated immediately.  The restaurant is very stylish with dim lighting and lots of wood-grain decor.  The music was loud in an enjoyable way and not in an "I-can't-hear-what-others-at-my-table-are-saying" sort of way.  That evening, they were playing some early 2000's R&B and Hip Hop (think JA Rule featuring Ashanti) that brought my wife and I back to high school / college and smiles to our faces.

Food wise, we initially ordered the Tuna Poke, Salmon Sashimi, and Spicy Garlic Noodles. We asked the waiter whether this was enough food, so after playing the "how hungry are you?" game, he politely suggested that we hang on to a menu.  It turns out that we were, in fact, HECKA hungry, so we added the Kung Pao Chicken Wings later on.

The food was excellent.  It was tough to pick a favorite among the dishes that we had.  I really liked the Spicy Garlic Noodles given the spice and texture.  The Kung Pao Chicken Wings reminded me of the Indo-Chinese Hakka staple, Chili Chicken, which I'm really fond of.  The Salmon Sashimi, with it's chilled avocado sauce, was great too.  Man, it really is hard to pick a favorite - trussss me!

I'm looking forward to going back and trying more dishes.
author: Sebastian N.

description:
A very special brunch place with great music! It's like a morning bar, just you can barely hear each other lol.

It's a all you can eat and drink dim sum brunch restaurant. We ended up paying $46.24 per person.

The drinks at the bar are good! Mimosa and sangria are just the right amount of alcohol to get you start the morning:)

They serve the food in small amount so you get to try everything if you have more than 4 ppl. I wouldn't say the food is amazing, but just like other dim sum and decent Chinese food places.

At last, eating is all about the mood and the environment!
author: Amie Z.

description: Had the pad Thai and tacos. As recommended by the helpful waitress. Delish! Would recommend this place to travellers looking for fresh, fast and great service.
author: Megan E.

description:
So I went there last night (Sunday night) and we were seated right away, sweet!
The place is pretty small, but very lively, music was really upbeat and yet kinda on the loud side, so was a little hard to have a conversation. Staff was really helpful and attentive. 
This is what we had to eat:
*Chinese Chicken salad- pretty tasty
*Korean Tacos- Amazing!!
*Duck lettuce wraps- Nom Nom
author: Kevin B.

description:
The premise behind Chubby Noodle sounds like it could be a big failure - mediocre food and watered down drinks for a rowdy college bunch.  Thankfully, Chubby Noodle FAR exceeds expectations.

I went for brunch this past weekend with a friend, and we ordered the entire menu (less the two soups) and four drinks each.  The food was awesome.  I really enjoyed every dish on the menu and was very pleased that everything came out piping hot and obviously very fresh.  My favorite dishes were the Breakfast Jook, the Shanghai Dumplings, the Peking Duck Steam Bun, and the Salt & Pepper Prawns - but, honestly, I really would eat every dish again.  

For cocktails, we tried the cold tea and the sangria, and we preferred the sangria.  I love that the drinks come with tiny neon ducks in them, and the waitstaff let us take ours home (in fact, they even gave us an extra one on the way out).  

For all that we ate and drank, I still can't believe it was only $35/person.  This is a great, great deal.  And the environment is so fun!  There were a couple of big groups celebrating various occasions and they made the atmosphere so upbeat.

Chubby Noodle loses a star because (a) the music is WAY too loud (we were screaming the entire time) and (b) the service was very slow and apathetic.  Our waitress forgot a number of items in our order and rarely came back to check on us, meaning that we had to keep chasing her or someone else down in order to get drinks or more food and make good use of our 90 minute bottomless brunch.
author: Tay H.

description: Cool vibe, food was okay though. We got spicy garlic noodles, korean pork tacos, and papaya salad. The spicy garlic noodles not too spicy, the noodles could be a bit more chewy :) Korean pork taco was not bad, the flavor didn't really get me. Papaya salad was refreshing, great to have with the spicy garlic noodles. Service/food could get a bit slow since they have a bunch of takeout orders.
author: Jaclyn C.

description:
Oh, Chubby Noodle...why are you SO good? Id be lying to you if I said I didn't crave this place at least once a week. While I have to suppress my cravings and save my visits for a cheat day, I honestly think Chubby Noodle is one of the best places to grub in SF. 

Favorite things?
Garlic noodles
Korean Pork Tacos (OMG )
Wontons
Green beans 
Fried Rice 
Poke 

The only reason I've taken off a star is because seating, when available, is pretty tight. It can get super hot in here with their open kitchen format. Honestly though, you don't really care once you're seated. They are also notorious for playing the best music ever (see: "Chubby Noodle Marina" playlist on Spotify)
author: Mandy A.

description:
I've tried both locations and slightly prefer the Marina spot since it boasts big communal tables and a semi-open kitchen. I'd call it Mission Chinese's equally hip steb-sibling but with more multicultural Asian roots. It's also a shared plate experience with a solid Japanese beer and soju collection. 

Top picks in the Marina:
SPICY GARLIC NOODLES - pile on the noodles! What's not to like about charred garlic and jalapeno? It reminded me of SO's black bean noodle dish, sans black beans. 
SALT & PEPPER SHRIMP - sure, it's a modest serving but every bite is worth it.
GARLIC GREEN BEANS - these were stupid good. Almost better than the meat dishes which sounds silly. They caramelize it perfectly so it's smoky, garlicky and sticky delicious. 

The BBQ pork fried rice and Kung Pao Wings were decent but not remarkable enough to make much of an impression. 

Top picks in North Beach:
CHUBBY FRIED CHICKEN - that buttermilk brine though. It's a beast to do at home (multi day process = agonizing). I always appreciate those who go an extra mile to create juicy chicken. These are bone-free so have at it!

My primary gripe is the pounding music they blast at major decibels (at both locations mind you) and then crank up even further as soon as it becomes dinner hour. I mean ... I understand the sly party throwing rule of always having your music a notch higher. It encourages guests to get close to talk to one another but this is club-level loud. That or I'm just getting old and cranky.
author: Faith Y.

description: Hottest place in the Marina. Seriously. I absolutely love the music they played (Gucci, 21 savage, Waka Flocka) and the food is BOMB. I got the Korean tacos, BBQ pork fried rice (huge chucks of pork)and Kobe Beef chow mein. Super good! Highly recommend the Korean tacos. The bartender was amazing and let me try out this coconut drink he made (which was super good). Will definitely be back!!
author: Shen D.

description:
This was my first time at chubby noodle on recommendation from a friend, and it did not disappoint! It's tapas style which was great for our group of 6, and we pretty much just ordered everything. The food is delicious, you can't go wrong with whatever you pick but I would definitely recommend the tacos, the bbq ribs, and the garlic noodles. Yum!!

The atmosphere is fun, they play hip hop music and everyone on the staff was really friendly. The service was great and the food came out really fast. The staff was very accommodating when we asked to switch our table for more space. 

This place is my new obsession!
author: Jaclyn A.

description:
Found this place, here on Yelp! Wanted some fusion, and a place close by. We got there right when they opened, sat down, had some recommendations made to us. Tapas style, order a few dishes to share. 

Bbq pork fried rice with a fried egg, I could eat this all day. AMAZING flavor and BIG pieces of bbq pork. Ummm whole lotta awesomeness.

Spicy garlic noodles with fried chicken. The fried chicken were bite sized pieces fried to crisp perfection and spicy. Noodles were good, not much garlic flavor in them, I felt all the flavor was in the chicken which in turn complimented the noodles quite well. 

Korean bbq pork tacos. HOLY COW BATMAN, these are the bomb! I can't describe the explosion of flavor that happens to your tastebuds other than to get your butt in there and try them. 

I refreshed my palette with a pear/champagne cocktail that was yummy. 

My favorite part was the kick ass old school 90's R&B/hip hop tunes that were bouncing in the background. Nothing like a little Nate Dogg while eating tasty food!  we'll visit here again, for sure!
author: Lesley B.

description: Food was good. The "cold tea" was delicious. The service was SUPER slow. In the first 50 minutes I sat there I only had a pork bun and some noodles. I felt like they were trying to keep us from fully enjoying the all you can eat aspect of the experience. They also tried to bring us salad three times even though we told them no salad. They ended up bringing a salad a fourth time around and we just kept it because we were tired of correcting them.
author: Tushar K.

description: Just got into San Francisco and was looking for something fast and good. The food was great, service was excellent and everything came out fast. Music was great too!
author: Fran L.
